Press_News_Content.p:
Your Birthday?
30 October.

Your first break in the music scene?
Anand and Anand- RD Burman

You have been in the music scene for so long and been as successful in films as well as non-films. What is more fulfilling?
It used to be Bollywood music.

Where do you think the music industry is going? Do you believe that there is a market for non-film music in India?
I see no market for non-film music to be hits, even film music gets markets only in case of caller tunes and mobile revenues.

Why have you taken the digital approach?
I believe that if songs sung by me for Bollywood Films can become big hits as Caller Tunes or Ringtones, why should I not give it a try with music that has my creative freedom to create it for my fans.

Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?
Gul chand sitare ho na ho - The lyrics of this song picture a broken heart with a sweet melody making it very relatable as well as listenable.
Chandni ki Palki Main - The song on its own has a mix of styles that also takes you into the sounds of the 70s which were more into swing and melody. The lyrics is a dedictaion to beauty.

Zara Zara in Gesuuon ko Suljhane Do - The pace of the song is very foot tapping and the treatment to the song makes it very fantasy like. The intro piece in the song is the hook that lingers on long after the song is complete. A sudden end to the song makes you wish there was more.
If you were not a singer, what would you have been? -- Music Director
Your Inspiration or Mentor – Kishore Kumar
You Like - Mirror ;) myself
You Dislike - Hypocrisy
Singer - Me
Musician - Manvari’s song
Song - All Kishore Kumar and RD Burman song.
Your trademark - My voice and my spectacles

Your message to your fans
Keep on listening to me. I promise to give new everytime you hear.

Also please give a few lines about ArtistAloud.com
Digital is the present and the future. The opportunity of being able to be part of a musical revolution in the digital space which is already in its overdrive was tempting and wants to try this unconventional route to release unreleased music for my fans.

Press_News_Content.p: A brand new season of little champ is back in little different format.

An age old debate between girls and boys to prove the superiority will now exchange blows musically. Veteran singers and judges on the show Abhijeet Bhattacharya and Alka Yagnik have formed their teams of boys and girls respectively.
Melodious Alka expresses her excitement, “A different kind of thrill is experienced when there is a clash between girls and boys in any kind of competition.
It will be the USP of this season”. But Abhijeet maintains, “Though we have formed a team, for us the contestant is not a girl or a boy. We will purely be judging them on their ability”.

Press_News_Exclusive.p: A Hindi Rock group that motivates its listeners through its music.

Press_News_Content.p: Roopkumar Rathod- 10th June and Sunali Rathod - 17th February

Press_News_Content.h6: Why have you taken the digital approach?
Press_News_Content.p: RR & SR - The future of all industries is going the digital way. Computers are the way of life. Since music is the mirror of the society digital media activity is inevitable.
Press_News_Content.h6: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?
Press_News_Content.p: Sawariya-An Interesting and Intoxicating bend of lounge and classical. This Song is sure to catch the fancy of all music lovers.
Dhuaan - A high class poetry combined with the new age music.. A different experience altogether.
Beet Jaat Narkha - A True blue fuson between the Indian and western classical. This is a rare bandish in raag des from the vast ocean of Hindustani classical repertoire..

If you were not a singer, what would you have been?
RR---Oh...I would be a professional photographer for sure...
SR---An actor no doubt

news.Press_News_Title: Today most singers seem clone to each other: Abhijeet

Press_News_Content.p: After judging Little Champs and Star Voice of India, the renowned singer Abhijeet Bhattacharya is all set to preside over yet another reality show Ek Se Badkar Ek on Zee TV. Here he speaks out in a free wheeling interview on this new format of the show and the ill that plague the genre…

p.strong: What is different about Ek Se Badkar Ek?

Press_News_Content.p: This unique show is a fusion of singing and dancing. But I am concerned only with the 8 singers. Since the contestants have already arrived from previous reality shows, it’s not a talent hunt as for now. It's not also about whether they are good or bad singers. The matter, only counts, is how they sing on any particular day. I will not be swayed by emotions or by excuses that their throat was bad. If you are bad on a particular day you are bad.

p.strong: Don’t you think reality shows have been done to death?

Press_News_Content.p: The public is liking them right, so what’s the problem? Having said that it’s better than the never ending sas-bahu drama’s, where each woman is having 4 affairs and number of illegitimate children, we at least show true talent getting their space in the sun.

p.strong: Is the fusion, you have mentioned, exciting enough?

Press_News_Content.p: Yes, if the singer is bad then the actor will have to do the extra bit in his dance to save the day. Neither Ahmed nor me will try to save any bad couple. We have our reputations to protect. I can assure you that in this show the views of the judges and audience will always be the same.

p.strong: You seemed unhappy with Voice Of India, hence you stayed away from the finale?

Press_News_Content.p: I had some previous engagement in the States, which I could not cancel. But I was not happy with the elimination of Toshi and Abhas as well. Plus, the presence of one clone of Kumar Sanu was troubling me a lot. And what was the use of attending the final and sitting like mute spectators!

p.strong: The winner Ishmeet was your favourite, yet once you attacked him and said that he should go out…

Press_News_Content.p: That was my strategy. For, after my attack, he was inundated with votes from Punjab, while I got lots brickbats. I felt I had to do something to prevent a good natural singer from going out.

p.strong: Something similar had happened in Little Champs as well.

Press_News_Content.p: A lot of sympathy votes were going to Diwakar as because he was blind. I opposed that and eventually the dark horse Sanchita started to get ahead.

p.strong: Your take on SMS voting…

Press_News_Content.p: It's needed to retain audience interest. And it's not all that SMS based shows mint money; only a few do.

p.strong: What about judges fighting among themselves?

Press_News_Content.p: It used to happen earlier as well but then it would be edited. Now things are reverse edited. This drama started when singers, who did not have much work, started becoming judges on reality shows. What further annoys me is the fact that you have actress who can’t speak Hindi properly judging such shows. A pop singer is totally ruining a classical number and you are praising him/her. Only a singer should judge such shows.

p.strong: Singers coming to the forefront through such format…

Press_News_Content.p: Yes, agreed. Singers have become very popular but there is a flip side as well. Today most singers seem clones of each other. There are a few, even on this show, who I will never encourage. Earlier each singer had his own distinct style which is not available in these shows.

p.strong: Your take on them not doing playback?

Press_News_Content.p: Honestly speaking, I am not too gungho about the current playback scene. No effort is taken these days to make sure that the singer’s voice fits the actor. Any nonsense singer is taken. Mind you, I am not talking about the composition or the lyrics.

p.strong: Since you are coming up with your new album, are you not afraid of piracy?

Press_News_Content.p: Many other revenues streams have opened up, like royalties from FM stations and ring tones etc. Agreed, piracy is a major issue but all the loss accrues to the music company. Even if these losses are plugged we singer’s will not get an extra paisa, so why should we bother!

news.Press_News_Title: Aishwarya Majmudar - High on Woman Power

p.strong: OF late, it’s been raining reality shows. So, why another story on the finalists of a singing contest?

Press_News_Content.p: Well, simply because Chhote Ustaad is the only show where two girls have made it to the finals. Bubbling with fizzy endorphins on their feat, we catch hold of the two lil’ girls and quiz them about their love for singing, dreams and women power!

Their initial inaccessibility for a telephonic interview is, no doubt, irksome. However, our ‘stars-in-the-making’ have quite a ‘spring in their voices’ when they finally greet us over the phone. It’s perhaps their chirpy eagerness to make it big, which lets all irritation melt away.
And so we throw a clichéd volley of queries at Aishwarya Majmudar, busy rehearsing for Chhote Ustaad’s grand finale on Saturday.

Aishwarya seems particularly delighted because of her favourite Amitabh Bachchan’s presence at the recently shot promo shoot for the finals. “Amit uncle’s too cute! He noticed that I was wearing a shirt too large for my size and immediately adjusted my collar, saying Ye mera shirt aapko kisne de diya.”

Jokes apart, their mommies-in-tow have been quite a support system post the grilling rounds. Says Aishwarya Majmudar, “I’m not tensed about studies. My school in Ahmedabad has already promoted me to class X. But yes, a lot of hardwork is involved for this contest too.

We are doing five hours of riyaaz daily, besides a 2-3 hour choreography class and shoots. I guess it’s the price for success! With sparkling confidence, moms-in-tow and well-rehearsed statements, these girls seem lil’ stars indeed. Maybe, Big B wasn’t exactly joking when he whispered to the show’s camera person “These are stars of today, hum to junior artist hain.”

Press_News_Featured.p: Aishwarya seems particularly delighted because of her favourite Amitabh Bachchan’s presence at the recently shot promo shoot for the finals. “Amit uncle’s too cute! He noticed that I was wearing a shirt too large for my size and immediately adjusted my collar, saying Ye mera shirt aapko kisne de diya.”

We are doing five hours of riyaaz daily, besides a 2-3 hour choreography class and shoots. I guess it’s the price for success! With sparkling confidence, moms-in-tow and well-rehearsed statements, these girls seem lil’ stars indeed. Maybe, Big B wasn’t exactly joking when he whispered to the show’s camera person “These are stars of today, hum to junior artist hain.”

news.Press_News_Exclusive: Going places in a short span. Promises to make it bigger

p.strong: Your Names Your Birthdays

Press_News_Content.p:
Ritesh Ranjan Sahai 29th July
Aneeta Uniyal Sahai 21st February
Sanjay K. Pathak 3rd November
Rahul Srivastava 3rd July
Amit Joshi 16th April

p.strong: Your first break in the music scene as a band.

Press_News_Content.p: First album released in 2004 on Kosmic music.

p.strong: How did you guys come together as a band?

Press_News_Content.p: We met, one after the other, for the purpose of making a show in Lucknow during the summers of 1996, everyone to contribute a bit to it. Ritesh with his poems, Rahul and Sanjay with guitars, vocals and composing and Aneeta again with vocals and later with percussions also. We would spend hours together, sometimes even days and nights. We would eat, sing, wander, quarrel and resolve, gossip, ponder and dream together. We came to Pune sometime around November of 2005, Amit joined us here. Talaash is a beautiful sense of sharing. With the passage of time we became a family, and then a band.

You all were based in Lucknow and have a strong Hindi foundation. Do you believe that that is required to sing in Hindi? Yes, that way only you get to feel the minute nuances of the language and then be able to express better.
.

p.strong: Your song is very acoustic. Do you prefer playing unplugged or wired up?

Press_News_Content.p: Surely unplugged, as it suits to our simple music.

p.strong: You have performed the world over. Do you prefer performing live or recording in the studio?

Press_News_Content.p: Performing live is always a preference, you have the spontaneous connectivity. But as we ought to record a creative piece in a studio, we try our best to tap the similar feel of expressions, as in a live performance.

p.strong: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com ?
Both the songs are nostalgic:

Press_News_Content.p: Mohalla is about the boundless warmth and affection we enjoyed with our neighbours. There are some words or phrases in the song signifying the typical architecture of the houses where we stayed for long. But the very essence of this mohalla (the song) is not limited to a certain part of the land, it is spread all over the country, may be across the world.
Patang is a passionate sport with no age bar. It is so beautiful and vivid. We have tried to cover almost all the emotions and colours, from flying to crying.

p.strong: Your Inspiration or Mentor for the Band

Press_News_Content.p: Inspiration has always been the family and friends. They kept expressing their interest and faith in our work since the very beginning and through all the ups and downs and the odds of life they have always stood by us. And when we think of a mentor we know that the band owes a lot to Sri. Promod Shanker of Delhi, late A.K.Gargory (dadu), Sri Vinod Chattrerjee, Ustad Gulshan Bharti, late A.R. Basu (ICCR), Prof. Ruprekha Verma (Ex. VC, Lucknow University), Dr. Sabra Habeeb and Dr. P.K. Ghosh (Lucknow University), all from Lucknow.

p.strong: You Like..

Press_News_Content.p: Originality and Honesty.

p.strong: You Dislike..

Press_News_Content.p: Selfishness and Hypocrisy

p.strong: Your Favorite as a Band/Singers

Press_News_Content.p: Begum Akhtar, Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan, Shobha Gurtu Ghulam Ali, Jgajit Singh, Lata, Kishore, Rafi, Manna Dey, Mukesh, Beatles, Eagles, Simon and Garfunkel.

p.strong: Musician/s

Press_News_Content.p: Ustad Bismillah Khan, Ustad Amjad Ali Khan and Ustad Zakir Hussain, S.D. Burman, Madan Mohan, A.R. Rahman, Frank Zappa, John Williom and Tommy Emmanuel.

p.strong: Song/s

Press_News_Content.p: Thandi Hawa Ye Chandni Suhani. by Kishore Kumar, Bhor bhai by Indian Ocean, Mai ri.. by Euphoria and Words by Bee Gees.

p.strong: Your trademark

Press_News_Content.p: The peepal leaf and the sound of acoustic guitar.

p.strong: Your message to your fans

Press_News_Content.p: By the grace of God, we are on a journey to produce meaningful poetry with soft and soothing melody for our fans everywhere in the world. We expect that this relationship of love shall continue for ever.

ArtistAloud.com
ArtistAloud.com is one of the most wonderful things happening in our times. We hope that this would be a big turning point in the lives and career of the innumerable talented artistes across the country, especially for those who have a very little exposure or hardly have that at all.

The platform has offered the artistes a huge opportunity to showcase their work to the world that too without compromising the honesty of the creation. On behalf of the entire artist community we wish that the endeavour called ArtistAloud.com become a milestone.

p.strong: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com ?
Both the songs are nostalgic:

Press_News_Featured.p: Mohalla is about the boundless warmth and affection we enjoyed with our neighbours. There are some words or phrases in the song signifying the typical architecture of the houses where we stayed for long. But the very essence of this mohalla (the song) is not limited to a certain part of the land, it is spread all over the country, may be across the world.
Patang is a passionate sport with no age bar. It is so beautiful and vivid. We have tried to cover almost all the emotions and colours, from flying to crying.

Press_News_Content.p: Asha Bhosle’s grandson is as unique as the way he writes his name.
Chin2 Bhosle of the Band of Boys gets chatty:

p.strong: Seems like you’ve been missing from action for sometime.

Press_News_Content.p: That’s not true. We’ve just been out of the media limelight. It’s a lot tougher now because the media is all about films these days. Indie-pop is relegated to a very sorry state of affairs. But we’re doing really well in the college circles.

p.strong: There have hardly been any boy bands in India when it comes to pop…

Press_News_Content.p: It’s a tough thing to do. We were formed in 2001 and everybody pulled out of their jobs. For one year we were jobless. We’ve seen tempers, fighting, problems at home, and that bonded us very together. It’s tough to form a band and keep it together… and that’s why the few pop bands that are formed, ultimately break up.

p.strong: What inspires your music?

Press_News_Content.p: My inspiration is just music. I can’t be a model… or an actor.

p.strong: Being Asha Bhosle’s grandson must have its share of pressure…

Press_News_Content.p: There was never any pressure to begin with because I didn’t take up music as a profession. I did my MBA… worked in an ad agency for two years where they made a 15-day break sound like a favour. When I finally quit, she [Asha Bhosle] was like, ‘Are you mad? It’s not easy making your way in the music industry.’ But I told her that I was lucky to have her surname and didn’t want any help unless I really asked for it. So I shunned that pressure from the very start.

p.strong: What are you doing for New Year’s Eve?

Press_News_Content.p: I’ll be in Delhi performing at Daffodils, Chattarpur on the 31st. I can’t think of a better way to celebrate it… it’s a complete high to perform in the city.

p.strong: What’s next?

Press_News_Content.p: I’ve recorded a solo album in which I’ve sung a song with my grand mom.

p.strong: What’s the one thing that sets you apart from the rest of the band?

Press_News_Content.p: I ride a cycle, wear chappals, shorts and a vest to parties even though my friends have repeatedly asked me to ‘look cool.’
Dhwani, a Kalyan-based rock band is touching the right notes to draw suburban music lovers to an alien dance floor.

Riding high on the warm reviews of their first two stage performances the band is all set to launch their first album online. Ek Ladki…, Tere Bina… and Tandav their first few compositions would be now available on the mouse click.

Last month the band made performed at the Acharya Atre auditorium and the Subhedarwada ground. “Suburbs are prepared to absorb pure rock. We have begun with fusion wherein we serve the audience with rock in a desi platter,” said Mayuresh Kelkar composer-cum-guitarist of the band. He however assures that one can expect some real head-banging material from the troupe in the New Year.

Nestled in the calm locales of Godrej Hill is their newly opened digital studio. It is therefore not surprising when Ashish Tiwari, support vocalist and lead singer for QUE tracks claims that their music is inspired from nature. “This very inspiration helped in naming the band,” adds Tiwari. Dhwani signifies sound. “Dhwani stands for sound that connects body, mind and soul,” he further explains.

Interestingly, the troupe also plans to go mobile on their music. Ringtones of the first album will also be available on the web. “A ringtone is the best way to cater to a niche audience. Every phone call can spread our music amongst people,” added Kelkar. Meanwhile, these young musicians also have to face the music of a strict 9-5 work schedule, sometimes even more erratic. “Our jobs keep us occupied throughout the week.

Weekends are exclusively for music,” chuckles Kelkar. He further adds, “We work for the stomach and jam for peace”. Busy switching to the soft rock and classical opt Kelkar feels that the band has ideal balance to change suburban rock culture.

Chandrashekhar the lead vocalist, also heard on All India Radio (A.I.R) is the dark horse of the troupe. Ashish accompanies him with vocals while Snehal (Tabla), Bipin (Drum) and Mangesh (guitarist) make the ideal recipe for some peppy soul-stirring music.
On the quest for the young suburban rocker for couple of years, the band wants to bring rock in the mainstream music gallery.

p.strong: IMR: Hello CHANDRESH! So first of all on behalf of Team IMR, thanks for taking the time to talk to us. Tell us about DOL, after playing Live for so many years how you came up with the idea of DOL?

Press_News_Content.p: DOL: Well, about 4 years back Suraj happenend to call me for a one of show and that’s how we started jamming. We realized that both of us had the same creative urge and wanted to start a band that only played originals. So we started writing songs and recorded our first album HUMAN RACE.

p.strong: IMR: How was the response for the album HUMAN RACE as two of your songs were aired on VH1? Is the music scene same as it was before 10 years?

Press_News_Content.p: DOL: The response has been phenomenal! People sing our songs and request our songs at our gigs. The song being aired on Vh1 gave us an additional boost. The music scene has definitely changed. The audience has become a lot more open to bands playing originals and a lot of smaller venues have opened up. So it no more happens that 50 bands are vying for that one slot in a year!!

p.strong: IMR: What does DREAM OUT LOUD try to speak through their music & lyrics? As on one side we have song like ITS RAINING NOW and on other side we have heavier song like HUMAN BEINGS.

Press_News_Content.p: DOL :Well this might sound clichéd but we write about what we feel our experiences, emotions etc. So if we feel that the subject of the song requires a mellow arrangement then that’s how it turns out to be.

p.strong: IMR: Tell us about your upcoming 2nd Album, what it is all about?

Press_News_Content.p: DOL:Its called A MOMENT OF WEAKNESS and we are still in the stage of finalizing what tracks go in there. Although I must say It has been a great leap for us creatively.

p.strong: IMR: Your new songs give a different feel, its heavier and technical as compared to HUMAN RACE, is DOL undergoing a genre change?

Press_News_Content.p: DOL: Yeah we are pretty much finding our sound and we are able to express the subject matter a lot more creatively as I said earlier. We don’t really think about the genre while writing songs and leave it upto the people to decide what they want to categorize it under!

p.strong: IMR: Tell us about the song SOUTH INDIAN BOY, as you guys play it live but its not there in the Album? What was the idea behind this song, as the audiences really enjoy this song?

Press_News_Content.p: DOL: The song was written about Suraj’s cousins Father. In an orthodox family music is always looked down upon especially ROCK. So the song talks about what the father feels when he has a son who is rocker! And the song is a funny take on the same... Most youngsters connect with this subject as they go through that almost every other day! The song dint fit into the human race album as the album was very serious and now since there is a huge demand for the song it may be released as a single soon.

p.strong: IMR: Your favorite song from the Album, the song you enjoyed the most while composing and which is nearest to the style of music you play?

Press_News_Content.p: DOL: Well the songs from the new album that have shaped up very well are LABYRINTH, FEET BACK ON THE GROUND.

p.strong: IMR: I always keep hunting for great bands/records. Please recommend a few that have influenced you or the band as a whole?

Press_News_Content.p: DOL: Our main influences have been WHITESNAKE, EXTREME, STEVE VAI, JOE SATRIANI, DREAM THEATRE, SEAL, STING.

p.strong: IMR: Our reader would really appreciate if you would like to tell us something about your website

Press_News_Content.p: DOL: I have been teaching personally for a long time now & I always wanted to have a website where I could put up a few lessons and that’s how it all began. The lessons are such that it would help a Guitar player who has stagnated and is looking for a few tips and ideas pertaining to different styles. Now I get a lot of people who want to learn from me once they go through the website. I hope to do a few more videos and put it up in the future.

p.strong: IMR: DOL is really doing great, would you like to give any message to our readers?

Press_News_Content.p: DOL:Thank you for saying so!! One line - Follow your Dream and work hard to achieve it!!

p.strong: Let me ask you some typical interview questions. How and when did you form your Band “Ektheband”?

Press_News_Content.p: The name of the band is actually ‘Ek’ and this name came about in a hurry when we had to register for our first live gig and didn’t have a name J . Shashank just thought of the simplest name he could think of and registered us. But in retrospect, and also coincidently, it signifies the very elements of our music, i.e. simplicity and at the same time, varied level of interpretations and subtle complexities.

p.strong: Which singer in Indian music do you admire most? Who is the most favourite Rock Icon?

Press_News_Content.p:
A lot of them. All the members have different choices ranging from kishore kumar, KK, Shanker Mahadevan, to SP Balasubhramaniam.
We have a lot of favorites when it comes to rock music. Some of them :
Pink floyd,
The Beatles,
The Porcupine tree

Myband: As you say “simplicity is the ultimate sophistication” – how do you maintain it or work on it practically while composing a new number, its music arrangement and its rhythm?
Ans: We don’t ‘try’ to maintain this saying as such. But yeah it invariable comes into our work as we all believe that simple music is the most heart felt . Yes, musical brilliance is not always about a highly complex and technically challenging composition. It’s more about how we incorporate subtle yet complex bits into the songs. A good song should be catchy, but at the same time rich musically. This is what good music is all about and we hope we can continue to get better at it as we go along

Myband:
Is there any meeting point between pure Indian classical music and Western rock music?
Ans: The meeting point is music itself. You can listen to varied genres, styles etc of music but in the end the basics remain the same and music of any kind will always be based on the different combination of the basic 12 notes.

Myband:
Fusion between Indian classical or semi-classical music and acoustics of western music (for exemple your “Darbari Jam”) enriches both the forms mutually or it just a way to popularize classical music for mass appeal – what do you think ?
We are definitely not here to promote any particular genre of music. While it is true that some of our songs enrich both forms of music, it is truly our passion for good music that has brought us here. No other ulterior motives…..seriously!
But yes. It does ‘popularize’( through we are too small to do that ) Indian classical music and we are glad it does, as there’s no other form of music that richer that Indian classical music.

Myband:
Which genre will you call for your song “ Kya yeh sach hai” ? This particular song can be a mainstream Hindi song .
Ans:- Yes it can be a mainstream hindi song and we don’t see that as being an issue. While we want to play in the fusion/rock space, mainstream songs like these add that extra colour to our set list and we are cool with that.

Myband:
Do you all think that Shashank, the vocalist gets the most attention of the audience?
Ans: It is that Lead Vocalist gets the most attention in a Band as he has the responsibility of connecting with the audience. We have no problems with that as we are here just to play good music. Though we do feel sorry for the bachelors on the band who are probably more deserving from a you-know-what standpoint!!

Myband:
How do you practice everyday? Jointly or individually ? Does Shashank, your vocalist practice “riwaz” of Indian classical music e.g. Khayal, sargam and taan ?
Ans: Certain secrets should never be disclosed : Baba Aveer ( guitarist Ek )

Myband:
In your team members, who conceives a new number first? Who writes the lyrics and how do you tune it? I mean it is a team work from the beginning or after the song is composed other members like guitarist and drummer add their portion of it?
Ans: Someone comes up with a tune and we kind of start building on it. Any new song will get refined along the way and we are constantly bettering even some of our well known compositions and it is a truly evolutionary process.

Myband:
How difficult it is to compose songs after songs keeping the pressure of popularity of the would-be song in mind? I think this is critical and difficult.
Ans: Its not. We create the way we feel it. We don’t compose music keeping a particular audience in mind. That’s why we say, We are EK and this is what we play.

Myband:What are your gigs in coming few months ?
Ans: We are actively playing in the Bangalore music circuit now. Most recently we played at Bangalore Central, KYRA and Opus. We do have a show coming up at Purple Haze.

Myband:
When do you have plan to release your own album?
Ans: Well, an album is really for bands who want to be in the “been there, done that” category. Commercially speaking, albums are not viable anymore, but from a band profile standpoint an album to our name will definitely help. So we are not ruling this out yet, but we do not have immediate plans though.

Myband:
Do you want to take up music as profession ?
Ans: Yes, The thing that we love to do most of all is Music and it would be a boon to do it full time.

Myband:
Do you all jointly as a team chase any specific dream? How do you want to place “Ektheband” after another 5 years?

Ans: Other than a few more strands of grey hair on all our heads, I hope nothing changes and we are still together as a band. Of course, we want to be a household name by then and this goes without saying. And more than that, continue creating good music .

Myband:
One last question, you have the chance to give one piece of advice to the young and new rock bands from India. What would it be?
Ans: Strengthen your basics and do not follow trends but create your own trends. Explore Indian heritage. Keep on rocking and go after your passion and the whole world is your stage…cheers!

p.strong: Your Birthday

Press_News_Content.p: 9TH JULY

p.strong: Your first break in the music scene.

Press_News_Content.p: Awara Baavaren from the film sapnay was a major break.

p.strong: You have been in the music scene for quite a while now. You keep disappearing and coming back with a bang. Is that planned or by chance?

Press_News_Content.p: Firm Principal and values, a non compromising nature and also the need to sing with dignity have contributed towards my songs treasury but my Happy-Go-Lucky, Content attitude could also be somewhat a part of the reasons for disappearing now and then, and yet knowing for certain that I will always be back by the grace of god and the will of my dead fans, with whose positive energies all that has been showered upon me has been declared a Hit.

p.strong: You have been involved with various social causes including issues related to women. Can you tell us something about that?

Press_News_Content.p: Since childhood there has been an intense concern in my for the injustice and atrocities heaped on women. I am glad that today my plea for women empowerment (also saving the girl child) is being heard and hopefully adhered to. Saving lovely GOA and concern for children (Drive against drugs and pedophiles) have also been on my agenda. I have been given so much by human beings who have been in their own way from time to time my god and I will always strive to give back extensively my time and energies to such causes.

p.strong: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

Press_News_Content.p: SHE IS A LEADER is a song very close to me that I have composed and written myself. It is an ode to the woman of today that I salute to and believe that she has empowered herself inspite of all her hurdles.
MAULA ALI is an almost classical SUFI based song, Composed by NAZAKAT ALI and arranged by HYCINTH D’SOUZA. IT is an intense heartfelt call to the heavens to make life more livable for human beings.
MERA YAAR MILADE is a rocking SUFI QAWWALI, which one would want to tap ones feet to. IT refers to ‘YAAR’ as GOD, and describes the love of a Devotee to that one god with many names.

p.strong: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

Press_News_Content.p: Am glad I am sincerely also referred to as a social activist which is an integral part of my living and I always wanted to make great , meaningful, issue – solving cinema. Hopefully someday I will inshallah !

p.strong: Your Inspiration or Mentor

Press_News_Content.p: GOD of course. My revered Guru SRI RAVI SHANKAR, my family and friends, and an endless list of good people who are actually the real reason why I am answering an interview such as this.

p.strong: You Like

Press_News_Content.p: People , most animals, Kindness, Upholding of values respectability to all especially women & Sensitivity & having Fun!!!

p.strong: You Dislike

Press_News_Content.p: Hurting any creature physically or emotionally, Non-concern to human Values, Disrespect to anyone especially Women (I Denounce it) and Insensitivity, and not having Fun!!!

p.strong: Your Favorite

Press_News_Content.p:
Singer - Too Long LIST BLAH BLAH
Musician - LATE MICHAEL JACKSON
Song - EARTH SONG BY MICHAEL JACKSON

p.strong: Your trademark

Press_News_Content.p: MY supposedly Happy-Go-Lucky, Energetic & Sincere yet kind of naughty countenance (too many Genuine Endorsement on these) other than the well loved Bhwara Bhavaren Girl’

p.strong: Your message to your fans

Press_News_Content.p: My gratitude is so deep and from the core of my soul and will strive to never let you down and always respond with all my heart to your love which has been so genuine throughout. Wish you true happiness, success & joy in all your endeavors. God be with you and keep having Fun!!!

p.strong: Also please give a few lines about ArtistAloud.com?

Press_News_Content.p: Here was somebody who said that if you love your music and you know it and we understand it. I am very happy to be Artist Aloud as here are they who understands an artist’s heart, knows what we want to give to the whole world and really glad and happy to be Artist Aloud.

Press_News_Exclusive.p: Women empowerment is her motto and SHE IS A LEADER in propogating the same.

news.Press_News_Title: Himani Kapoor talks about her music, her life and controversies

Press_News_Content.p: For a city that shoulders the formidable tag of making dreams come true, Mumbai sure has been lucky for the Faridabad-born Himani Kapoor.

At 20, she has already been a Sa Re Ga Ma Pa finalist, anchored Antakhsari, and has a handful of films to her credit. She says the reality show helped her get some exposure and also brought her to Mumbai, a city that broadened her outlook.
This helped her bag the opportunity to host Antakshari with Sunil Pal. But after misunderstandings between Pal and Himani, Pal was replaced with Karan Oberoi.
In this interview, Himani spoke to us about the misunderstanding with Sunil Pal, her relationship with Vineet Singh and her upcoming projects.

p.strong: Which projects do you have in hand?

Press_News_Content.p: Since my voice is heavy, I am singing a wedding song in Bachna Ae Haseeno with Sukhji (Sukhwinder Singh) and Shekhar Ravjiani. I am also singing an item song for Bipasha Basu in an Abbas-Mustan film called Mr Fraud. I have to thank Aadesh Srivastava for all these projects though. Through him I got to sing in Chingaari. Because of that, Himesh Reshammiya asked me to sing in movies like Fool and Final and Aap Ki Khatir.

p.strong: You entered Bollywood after participating in Sa Re Ga Ma Pa. Tell us about your journey?

Press_News_Content.p: It has been a great journey. I still remember standing in the queue for the auditions. It was a long journey and it took a lot of time, but it was worth it. I was upset after I lost in the final, but it was a good opportunity. The show also allowed me to experience Mumbai’s culture, which I think is very positive. It changed my outlook on life. As far as my singing is concerned, the show really helped me improve.

p.strong: Aadesh Srivastava was your mentor. How was it working with him?

Press_News_Content.p: Everyone on his team received a lot of support from him. He not only coached us by telling us how to modulate our voices, but also helped us pick the right songs. In spite of his busy schedule, he made time for us. He really wanted us to succeed. He also pointed out the finer points, which only trained ears notice. We felt honored that such a big music director was guiding us.

p.strong: How was it being the host of Antakshari?

Press_News_Content.p: I initially wondered whether I should become an anchor. But it is a music-related show and music is what I want to be a part of, so I felt it was the right move to make. I had a lot of fun anchoring the show with Sunil Pal. It’s great to have been a part of such an iconic show; it gave me a lot of confidence.

p.strong: Tell us about the problem with Sunil Pal.

Press_News_Content.p: I know there was this whole thing in the news about how the two of us didn’t get along. But that’s not completely true. The media just blew it all out of proportion. There was no major misunderstanding. Sunil bhaiyya was very busy with other shows while we were shooting for Antakshari and because of that he was a bit unprepared. Sometimes he would forget his lines and so I would say them for him to save time. Maybe he didn’t like that and so he said that I was stealing his lines. But there was nothing more to it.

p.strong: There are rumours that you are seeing Vineet Singh. What do you have to say about this?

Press_News_Content.p: This is just loose talk. Whenever you enter the industry and get close to someone, you get linked with him. Vineet and I are just good friends. There were rumours about Karan Oberoi and me too, but the whole world knows Karan is seeing Mona Singh. So, I have learnt to ignore these rumours.

p.strong: Are reality shows real?

Press_News_Content.p: Whatever happened in Sa Re Ga Ma Pa was real. The success of this show made other channels start talent shows. I think controversies increase TRPs and this is what makes the show different from the others. In Sa Re Ga Ma Pa, because people said Vineet and I were going around, the TRPs were high already.

p.strong: What kind of music do you listen to and whom do you idolise?

Press_News_Content.p: I love listening to ghazals and Sufi songs. Though my style is Western, I enjoy Sufi songs the most. I idolise Lataji and Ashaji.

p.strong: When do you do your riyaaz?

Press_News_Content.p: I do my riyaaz every day for one hour. They say it’s best to do it in the morning. If I don’t have time for it in the mornings, I do it at any time in the day.

news.Press_News_Title: Manasi Scott - While the Music lasts

p.strong: Your Birthday

Press_News_Content.p: 31st December

p.strong: Your first break in the music scene

Press_News_Content.p: Live performance at a Hemant Trevedi show, Femina Chrysallis. The whole industry was present, especially those who gave work, I did a good job, Bombay Times supported me via a beautiful article written by Martin Dcosta and it was smooth sailing from here on!

p.strong: You are one of the most versatile entertainers in the industry who has built her name through live shows much before releasing an album. How have you achieved that?

Press_News_Content.p: Through my faith in God and in realizing that He is the best manager one can ever hope for! My career has really been a series of miracles and I learnt early on to just do my best and leave the rest to God!!

p.strong: You are now getting into acting. Do you feel this will work better for you as a singer or is it just another feather in the cap?

Press_News_Content.p: Everything I do in the entertainment industry is with a view to promote my music and me as a singer. I have acted before, theatre, serials, but music is my first love and I do believe to be a complete entertainer you must be able to present yourself and your music interestingly and here acting, comparing, modeling, all help tremendously.

p.strong: You have composed, written and sung the songs that you are releasing through this platform. Do you feel it is easier to sing one’s own compositions or when someone else composes for you?

Press_News_Content.p: I believe you know your own compositions better than anyone else and end up giving them more time, more of yourself and more effort, hence they may turn out better overall. The only place it really works for me to have composed the song I have sung is when I am shooting a video because here, knowing the song better than anyone else can really help you emote it the way it needs to be shown.

p.strong: Why have you taken the digital approach?

Press_News_Content.p:
Everything has become digital! No one buys cds the traditional way in a store - except die-hards like me who still like to OWN the hard copy, own a bit of the artiste this way. It’s an exciting medium that is instantaneous, reaches out to millions at once and is the way of the future of music.
Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com

Farmaanaa - is one of my favorites! Its sexy, filled with easy-loving, the rain, a great dance groove and it is song that has beautiful lyrics. It’s the kind of song that can help you make-up after a bad fight, make love or just shut out the world and make you happy!

Todona - is the kind of song you can carry on your i-pod and enjoy anywhere! At a dinner, in a lounge, on a long drive I would loop it non-stop. For me music is about spreading the love and forgetting the past and forgiving and moving on. This is the perfect plea for love.

Kho gaye - is, vocally, one of most exciting offerings. It showcases different aspects to me a as singer and I really enjoyed recording this song, setting harmonies, the different arrangements. The fact that we chose NOT to lyrically interpret the chorus was also fun. It different, its soothing and its meant to transport you to a place you love - I hope it does!

p.strong: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

Press_News_Content.p: A pilot.

p.strong: Your Inspiration or Mentor

Press_News_Content.p:
Every artiste I have heard. I have learnt a bit from everyone - though Whitney Houston, Abba, Celine dion and Barbara.
Streisand cds were my original teachers!!!

p.strong: You Like

Press_News_Content.p: Simplicity in thought. Money. Music. Laughter. Good movies. Shopping. Travelling. Luxury. Food.

p.strong: You Dislike

Press_News_Content.p: Complexity.

p.strong: Your Favorite

Press_News_Content.p: Singer Whitney Houston, Amy Lee (lead singer Evanesence), Sonu Nigam, Shafqat Amanat Ali, Palash Sen, Fergie, Lady Gaga, Gwen Stefanie, Justin Timberlake

Musician Justin Timberlake, Slash, Meredith Brooks, J Lo, Janet Jackson, Madonna, Coldplay, James Blunt, Salim-Suleiman, Shankar-ehsaan-Loy, A.R. Rehman, R.D. Burman
Song Endless Summer Nights and Mora Saiyyan Moonh Se Bole Na

p.strong: Your trademark

Press_News_Content.p: Diversity

p.strong: Your message to your fans

Press_News_Content.p: Spread the music! Stand up against piracy! Support the music!

p.strong: Also please give a few lines about ArtistAloud.com

Press_News_Content.p:
There is no place for the musician to really get out there and be heard and everything is net dependent today and everything is digitally bought on your mobile phone, laptops, ipods, everything is digital . and we have a platform here that can combine what an artist wants to get out there, sell the right way, or sell the way that the audience wants to buy it.. that’s way platform like this ArtistAloud.com. Three cheers!
Its a bold, new, innovative way at how independent artistes can be heard and I am proud to be on it. At a time when radio stations, television channels, the media and music companies in India have abandoned non-film artistes, Hungama has shown tremendous faith and gumption in supporting us and in allowing us to be heard and its about time we are - loud and clear! ArtistAloud is here!

Press_News_Featured.p: 31st December

span.span: I see no market for non-film music to be hits, even film music gets markets only in case of caller tunes and mobile revenues.

p.span: 21st February 1982.

strong.span: Your first break in the music scene?

p.span: When my first Ablum “Chaukrabha” released in Calcutta. It had my own composition, lyrics and all 6 rock songs are sung by me. One of the songs “Aae Aaskash” had a great response and soon will be getting it in Hindi and will name it as ‘Yea Aasman’.

strong.span: You have been associated with reality shows more often than anyone in the reality show scene. Why is that and how do you feel about this so called exposure platform?

p.span: In 2005, Rock Band-E-Mataram—A rock competition in which I participated and stood as the best Vocalist for my own Composed song ‘Aai Aakash”. It gave a great media exposure in term of press release and interviews and motivated me to continue further with wholesome confidence.

Then my journey of Championship in all shows continued with a brick breaker show like Dabur-honitus- 1920 Madhurkant (Calcutta)—it gave me a great fan following and featured me in all possible Magazine making me a Rockstar ;). They also produced my album named as “Kunjee Nebo Roddur” for which mastering was done in Singapore.

strong.span: You have composed the songs on ArtistAloud.com all by yourself. Do you feel this freedom of creativity is something that was missing in the industry?

p.span: Yes it was. The sound like progressive classical rock sounds as love ballad and is never found in any songs and composition till date. It gave me a great chance to showcase and share the hidden part as composer to all music lovers out there.

strong.span: Is it easier to perform on stage or record in a studio?

p.span: Both.

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach?

p.span: I believe in maximum reach. Digital is the future. It’s the consumer - our audience that decides the best content. I want to reach to that maximum number and keep making music for them. This interactive platform gives a chance to make what they want to hear. Unke junoon tak paunch na chahata hoon as I believe my voice and my songs.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: - It a love ballad song. During the listening you will for sure miss your love and at the same time one passes the message to its love.
It’s a sufi progressive song. A call to the almighty in despair.
- It’s a soft rock song. It’s for every common man. One can live their dreams while listening to it. Message of the song- Kabhi haar na manna.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: I never thought but still probably An engineer.
My Parents, Myself and my Guru Gautam Mukherjee
Making and Performing music.
Bhala bura bolna aur sunana---Bitching
Myself ,Lataji, Kishore Da & Rafique Sahab
- AR Rehaman
‘Show must go on’- Queen & Kahin Toh- Jaane Tu Ya Jaane Na.
Head bagging during performances and to jump on the audience.
Stay with me forever and ever ;) Keep Jamming with me.

p.span: 4th February, some time in the not so distant past!

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

p.span: Music scene?!?! As far as I’m concerned, those 2 words cover a very wide spectrum!!
In 1993 I had a rock band and played professionally at various clubs in Mumbai – Jazz by the bay, Razzberry Rhinoceros, FantasyLand and lots of colleges!
In the year 1999 I became an RJ with the then only radio station Mumbai had to offer – AIR 107.1 FM . . .
In 2000 I did a lot of musical professional theatre which involved singing and acting on stage and other than shows in Mumbai which also traveled to Dubai, Kolkatta, etc.
In 2001 I auditioned and joined India’s first (and only!) boy band .A Band of Boys, post which we’ve released 4 music albums, acted in a Bollywood movie and done countless shows in India and abroad!
In 2003 I did music direction for a Bollywood film (only God knows when that will launch!!)
In 2004 I VJ’d for a year with the then freshly launched Zee Muzic
In 2006 I helped launched what is today India’s larget networked radio station Big FM as the Programming Head for Mumbai
In 2007 I RJ’d for a bit on Big FM . . . .
All of them involve music, all of them (with the exception of 2007) were my first break!!!

strong.span: Why do you spell your name with a 2?

p.span: Because ‘1’ of me is not enough!! Because I love it when people appreciate my work and say (chin) -2 much!!! Because it’s alpha numeric which reminds me of those equation kind of math which I’m terrible at and almost flunked! Because it reminds me of what I’ll get if I put on weight and stop exercising (which I hate doing!!)! Because a rose by any other name will still smell the same! Because it reflects a little bit of creativity which reflects me! Because I like it!!! – You choose!

You have been with Band of Boys for a long time and you recently released your first debut album which featured your Grandma, the great, Ashaji. How did it feel going solo? Do you prefer going solo or as a band?

To set the record straight, the times we’ve had as a Band (and will continue to do so of course!) have been some of the wildest, freakiest, stupidest and best times I’ve ever had . . . Only a fool would want to end that and somehow I don’t see myself as one!! So, just for the record, though I’ve gone solo, ‘A Band of Boys’ will always exist (hopefully we’ll be singing toothless and with a cane in hand on stage when we’re 80!).

The first thing that struck me (in a nice way!) about gong solo is that you have complete control over your music, identity and shows. There no longer exists a ‘collective’ decision for everything. If you want to edit something to your style, you can or if you want to compose something that purely appeals to you, you can - without having a one-fourth say in the matter!! And that in itself helps you explore your identity and find your own footing. It’s a wonderful feeling to walk down this path of self discovery.

But if you ask me to choose between the two . . . Tough question! I can’t!! As I said earlier, the band is an inherent part of me. I love doing the things we do together travel, shows, parties, etc. which I would never be the same as a solo artiste! Yet, I love the new found sense of my individuality!! Situation is somewhat like this - what to do . . . Kaju khaoon ya pista!!!!!?!?!?! Love them both!!!

strong.span: Where do you think the music industry is going? Do you believe that there is a market for non-film music in India?

p.span: A resounding YES to the second question! But if you were to ask me how does one tap into it?!?! Well that’s a different ball game all together.

Our music industry per se is a very unique one, to be found no where else in this solar system! Why?! Well our music has always been driven by films which roughly translates to great aspiration and star value, humongous budgets and difficult-to-fight clout!!!
It’s not that film music is better than the non-film music oh no!!! There’s some great stuff out there being made all the time . . . It’s just that people don’t get to hear it.

If you hear a crappy song 500 times a day, on radio, TV and the internet - all the time – you (being a homosapien) are bound to, at some point, start liking it. Whether you want to or not! Believe me, you don’t have a choice – I too am a victim of this phenomenon!

And that’s what film music does today – it bombards you mindlessly. Don’t get me wrong though - there’s some great music being churned out in the industry and I, for one, am a huge fan of composers like A. R. Rahman, Vishal-Shekhar, Pritam, Shankar/ Ehsaan/ Loy - to name a few.
More to the point, the non-film market in India, to my mind, has a market and can never die. And here’s why -

Unlike film music, non-film music doesn’t work to a brief. There is no ‘situation’ or hero telling a heroine something or dictat from a director/ producer who wants a peppy hit or a slow ballad hit or a finger clicking hit (they always want a hit in whatever it is you make!!!). Non film music (and this is exactly how I make my music) is an inspiration that you want to express. Just as a poet writes a poem, a writer writes a book or an artist paints a painting . . . . Your art reflects your inspiration. You express what has moved you or touched you. And you hope that somebody identifies with your expression and is touched the way you are. And if one person agrees with your expression, he sets your soul aglow!! If that persons agreement is multiplied by over a million people, you have a resounding hit and make shitloads of money and life looks good! But, (and this is the most important part!) before the money comes the satisfaction of your private, personal expression being appreciated. And that’s what we live for. That’s our oxygen. If a piece of work is put out there, as a labour of love and in all genuineness, someone somewhere will appreciate it. That’s my guarantee!! So yes, the market has existed and will always exist!!

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: Sometime in 2006, the mukhda of this song was written when I was at a radio workshop in Ahmedabad! I was then the Programming Head of Mumbai of what is today India’s largest networked radio station, Big FM, and going though a lot of tension, angst, sleepless nights and chaos! I was sitting with a couple of radio jocks from Kolkatta, Mumbai and Guwahati, chatting, plucking on their guitar and this may sound spooky but out of the blue I started humming this tune and strumming the guitar! I quickly recorded it (as I tend to forget tunes extremely fast!!) and that was the genesis of this song.

To put my thoughts to words, full credit to my mother-in-law, Rekha Bhimani (unfortunately that word is associated with such negative connotations thanks to the soaps we have on TV today – saans! But let me tell you that word means only awesome’ness to me!! Just can’t understand what the hoopla is all about man!)

Anyway, so this song is all about the girl who never was beautiful enough to win a beauty pageant BUT whose aura and energy is so exquisite and pure that she can silence a room with her presence, whose laughter is so in synergy with nature that it’s musical . . . She’s the elusive teaser and through personal experience, not the girl I’d want to marry but the one for whose attention I would vie for . . . And as you may have guessed, I knew of just such a girl in my days as a college student! This song I dedicate to her. And if she reads these words, I’m sure she’ll know that I speak of her! And I hope, with all my heart, that she’s happy wherever she is, with her family and children and laughing that golden laugh of hers . . . .
This I shall always be proud of!

How it happened - I was busy recording at home one evening and as was her habit (when she was just about to turn 2), my daughter would normally plonk herself on my lap and start singing whatever came to mind or her heart desired!!!

This fortunate day, I had the microphone plugged in and prior to her singing this, Aditi (my wife) and me were discussing Asha Bhosle’s (my grand-moms) impending birthday. Little Mishka promptly came running into my studio, saw me recording some scratch stuff for my album, sat on my lap and disregarding anything that I might have been doing, held the mike and started belting it out!!!! I (with a little bit of irritation I must admit) stopped my maha-creative process to accommodate the 4th generation Bhosle genius and promptly pressed the record button.
What you hear is unprocessed, unedited and sheer inspiration (from whence I have no clue!!).

The guitar underlay I added much later just out of curiosity to see how well she held her sur. And I can, as an extremely proud father, say she’s done a commendable job! I’ll be playing this to all your boy friends Mishka Bhosle, so beware!!!

Grow old with me' is essentially every cliché you might ever have heard of in a song! Chin2 says “this song is a part of my life - this song is about my wife Aditi and me and has been written from the heart based on stuff we've done together! So if you're the kind of person who can look beyond the obvious and who can perhaps sense a slice of life in a song, I think you should definitely enjoy this one!
If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

If not a singer, ummm, I was well on my way to becoming a marketing/ advertising professional . . . a radio jockey . . . a theatre actor . . . a video jockey . . . a . . . wow man, there’re sooo many things that interest me!! But somewhere deep down, aside from music I’ve always had a great love for flying! It’s just that I hated maths and thus never pursued it professionally but if you were to come home you’d see the three hard earned flight training certificates I have acquired through hours of training and many sleepless nights . . . . on my computer . . . thanks to Microsoft’s Flight Simlator!

Somehow I’ve never drawn inspiration from people I don’t personally know. Like an Eric Clapton or Bob Dylan . . . Great guys, awesome work but I’m generally inspired by people who I interact with. For eg. Gino Banks (percussionist), Sheldon D’Silva (bassist), Sangeet Haldipur (keyboardist) . . . Young guys, fully dedicated to their art and can give any senior professional musician a run for their money at the age of 25! When Gino is tired after a long day of travel he unwinds by playing his drums for 2 hours!!! If that doesn’t inspire you, nothing will!
Humility
People who are driven by passion
People who talk and don’t do – All gas no shit! (lots of people like that in my industry!!)
People who have no respect for others – always late and not even remotely apologetic about the fact that they’ve taken your time for granted!
– Not one in particular – Jim Morrison, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, Frank Sinatra, Asha Bhosle, Gypsy Kings, Kishore Kumar (this could go on forever!)
– Louis Armstrong, A. R. Rahman
– You never can tell (Chuck Berry), Ajeeb dastan hai ye (Lata Mageshkar), Ballad of John and Yoko (Beatles), - hey this is unfair!! How can there be one favorite song?!?!!??!
My repartee, my sarcasm, my never taking anything in life too seriously, my pimples (which I’ll keep erupting into even when I’m 75 man!)

If you’ve identified what it is that gives you a solid kick in life, go ahead and do it!! Fame, fortune, recognition – all these things are fringe benefits, perhaps desired but definitely not sought after! Truly enjoy doing what you do and I guarantee you that the rest will follow! That’s the story . . . That’s my trip in life! And perhaps so should be yours! Keep rocking!
According to me, Artist Aloud platform gives away the way for one to concentrate on their own music. One cant find the way to locate such music, but now yes , on Artist aloud.com.
Thank you so much!

5th october,1993

strong.span: How do you juggle your life between music and school?

p.span: I study from home in the National Institute of Open Schooling and that makes it easier to cope with my studies as I do not have to go to school which saves a lot of time.

strong.span: You were recently given an award in Canada. Please tell us something about that

p.span: The Gujarati Business Associations of Toronto, Canada awarded me the "Gujarat Gaurav Award” for achieving International acclaim in the field of music by winning a nationwide talent hunt competition (VOI Chhote Ustad).
I was also invited as the guest of honor at the Worlds Largest
India
Day Parade at Madison Avenue, New York on August 16th,2009 by the Federation of Indian Associations .

strong.span: Do you ever plan to go into acting?

p.span: Sure for a musical film or something.

strong.span: Which languages are you most comfortable singing in?

p.span: I can sing in most any language as I love languages.

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach?

p.span: As music is universal, the digital approach makes you and your music accessible to the music lovers in any part of the world.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: – is a rocking song about me and teenage girls like me who are transforming from kids to young girls.
– is about dreaming of soaring to new heights and reaching your goals and ambitions , And in the process paying respect to all the people who have been a part of my journey .
– is a traditional Gujarati Garba with a flavor of rock music.

p.span: There is no way I would not have been a singer .
But my other interests are Archeology, Reading, Arts and Crafts, Badminton, Swimming, Wildlife, etc..
My parents and family .
Everything!
Nothing!
I do not have anything favourite in particular , But I am a musical person and so I respect and like everyone and everything to do with music .
Me Myself
"Believe in Yourself and Love your Work".

news.Press_News_Content:
ArtistAloud.com launched to promote unreleased music by independent artists
08 January, 2010 Hungama Digital Media has launched ArtistAloud.com, a digital distribution platform for unreleased music created by independent artists. According to Hungama, all artistes on board retain the publishing rights of their compositions and can take their music onto the physical medium via any record label.
ArtistAloud.com offers DRM (digital rights management)-free music at Rs 10 a piece. One can also download four songs at Rs 20. The songs are made available in mp3 format, for both PC and mobile devices. The website currently features songs spanning over six genres which range from alternative pop, classic Indi-pop, fusion, English rock, Hindi rock and Bollywood pop.
The ArtistAloud music library can also be accessed through Hungama’s domestic and international digital distribution partnerships comprising, mobile operators, Hungama.com, the BSNL storefront, iTunes, Rhapsody, Amazon MP3, and through the Tata Sky DTH platform.
Neeraj Roy, MD and CEO, Hungama Digital Media, has said, “Hungama’s new initiative, ArtistAloud.com, combines the possibilities of digital platform with great musical talent. It rests on two pillars -- giving each artist his freedom of expression and music lovers their right to choose from a wider offering.”
“Today, nobody supports or promotes the independent artiste and as a consequence good talent suffers. I am extremely happy that ArtistAloud.com is supporting and giving them a platform for promotion and I give them my aashirvaad wholeheartedly,” Asha Bhosle, a Bollywood playback singer, has said.
Shaan, another Bollywood playback singer, has added, “I appreciate the (ArtistAloud.com) effort as it aims to help independent musicians and music businesses thrive in the changing media environment. Importantly, the musician can directly connect with its audience without the mercy of any music company.”

p.span: 24th August 1988

strong.span: Your first break in the music scene?

p.span: A thumri in chingari for my most favorite actor Sushmita Sen.

strong.span: You started your musical career at a very young age. We saw you in SAREGAMAPA for the first time but were there ever any high musical moments prior to that show? Tell us a little about it?

p.span: I participated in a devotional song competition held at Navratra festival in Katra, Jammu and turned up as a first female to bag the first prize of Rs. 1,00,000 plus I believe, since then it was Mata Vaishno Devi's blessings that the career's graph started going high and high and since then there was no looking back!

strong.span: Your career seems to be climbing in the right direction but slowly and now you have come out with your own music. Is this your way of telling the industry that you can make it on your own?

p.span: Composing on my own was never planned, the tune just strike in the mind and I played on it, and then just to know if people like my composition, Artist Aloud is the best place to share the song!

strong.span: Where do you see yourself musically 5 years from now?

p.span: Probably in a studio, singing, for all the top films :) and busy traveling the world for the shows on public demand :)

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach

p.span: The season of Cd's and cassettes is expiring. When one needs a song, he/she directly searches for it on the internet so, to go digital was a one of a very impressive offer to be received by Hungama!

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: A pure hip hop number, where we tried to blend Punjabi without losing the essence and without using major instruments like Dhol, tumbi etc. People who like to hear pure punjabi will also enjoy it because the feel and the melody is purely Punjabi. Lyrically, the mood of the song is different but people would dance to it and yet relate to it as well.

- Its a song where the composer (Nakash-Sargam) and I have tried to incorporate and blend two different genres of music. By mixing lounge with Indian elements like flute, duff but yet kept the indian melody as the base of the song. The entire song revolves around the lyrics, the melody and the style of singing.

- The song has minimal arrangement and a lot of acoustic instruments. Its a story within a song. The structure of the song is very unique because unlike many songs, it has only one Antara (paragraph).
This song is a mix of Hindi and Arabic lyrics sung in a very Arabic Melody which is very captivating in the first 30secs itself. The song has been sung very effortlessly and with a lot of attitude.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: If I was not a singer, I would have been an architect.
Ustad Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan Sahab, Noor Jehan Madam, Madan Mohan and my Mother.
I like honesty
Lies.
- Lata di, Noor Jehan madam, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan Sahab, Rafi Sahab.
- Madan Mohan ji, Laxmikant Pyarelal.
- Mai ri main kaase kahu (Madan Mohan), Aaj socha to aansu bhar aaye (Madan Mohan), Sukh maahi (Ustad Nusrat Khan Sahab).
My tattoo on my right arm.
Everyone has a one life, so enjoy each moment of it. Keeping in mind that sincerity is a key to a happy life! Also, keep enjoying my songs and keep blessing me!
I believe that Artist aloud.com is the quick and simple way for all to get my exclusive songs. I wish all the luck and glad to be a part of it.

Aalok- 25th Aug 1981
Mayuresh-11th April 1978
Bipin-8th June 1980
Tushar- 4th June 1982
Ganesh-6th Sep 1988

strong.span: Your first break in the music scene?

p.span: Dhwani has been active in the jingle compositions arena. A corporate jingle composed for “you telecom” was Dhwani’s first commercial break. It is a relatively a young band, who hopes to grow with each passing year, in experience, in their music.

strong.span: How did you guys come together as a band?

p.span: Mayuresh and Bipin used to jam together. Bouncing off ideas about a band, Bipin and Mayuresh decided to give it a try. Aalok, basically had been interested in different genres from the start. Meeting Mayuresh for a classical recording, Aalok immediately showed an interest in the whole concept of Dhwani. Tushar being a common friend and also a very talented tabla player joined on board. The big search however was for a good drummer. After a couple of auditions, the drummer thing was at a standstill. Ganesh came in through another common friend of ours and after our first jam, this guy was here to stay.
Also one of the most important reasons binding Dhwani is their interest in experimenting in diverse and equally creative genres.

strong.span: What does Dhwani mean to the group?

p.span: Dhwani is an idea that has been nurtured and every member wishes to see it become a success.

strong.span: Your lead singer is an Indian Classical Singer. How do you’ll blend his influences into a rock genre?

p.span: Bipin is from a hard core rock background. Aalok comes from a very classical background. As aalok says, he always tries to complement the riffs and melodies with ragas complimenting those notes. That’s how the whole melody shapes up.

strong.span: Who do you see connecting to your music?

p.span: We do not frame music in any particular genre. Every artist in Dhwani has always believed in experimenting with different sounds. So that’s what we perceive our audiences to be. The Easy listeners. Not a hard core fanatic about a particular kind of music.

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach?

p.span: Dhwani believes that Digital approach is the futuristic approach towards music.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: is a song which strongly reflects on a man's philosophy on his life, his contemplations on his life gone by. The song also reflects his desire to connect with people as he continues his journey.
is a song on the prevailing situations which are plaguing the country currently. It symbolizes the need to change the callous attitude of the people.
is a very melody based track. It has given every artist in Dhwani an insight into his own self…his own being. His own core. That is precisely what this track intends to make every listener feel.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: Aalok has a degree in Economics and was pursuing Law when music happened. Trying to run away from his own music through a variety of educational excuses (lol)..music finally came to him. That’s when he realized that this was his destiny.

However fulfilling his destiny has been the hardest part. As put in his own words, “I can’t imagine my life without music now. Everything I do, I do it in terms of music. But there was a time when I used to face the conflict of having chosen music over a conventional profession every day. His Music has been his biggest support in those hard phases.
PT. Bhimsen Joshi, Ustad Rashid Khan, Smt Kishori Amonkar.
Great food. Great music.
Unethical behavior. People with an Attitude.
: Pt. Bhimsen Joshi
Ust. Shahid Parvez
Rozana by Amitabh Bachchan
Unique Vocals
Recognize your true potentials and always follow the dreams that you believe in. And be brave to face whatever comes your way in doing it.

ArtistAloud.com is an idea that for sure is going to change the way the music is delivered to the masses. Its high time now that a platform is built that convincingly expands the reach and horizons of Indian music and artists at the same time. Artist Aloud is an innovative idea and a step towards the same goal. Its our honor and pleasure to be a part of such great team!

p.span: Chandresh Kudwa
Suraj Jagan
Chandresh Kudwa - 9th Dec
Suraj Jagan - 11th May

strong.span: Your first break in the music scene as individual artists as well as Dream Out Loud?

p.span: : Got my first break with a jazz rock band called Aurora in 1987.
: I started out playing guitar at a very young age. Got together with some friends who wanted to form a pop band and that’s how I started gigging playing at functions.

As Suraj and I were pretty much in the same field of music we had seen each other perform at concerts. There came an opportunity where Suraj had to put together a make shift band to perform for a corporate party and that’s when he called me up and asked me if I was interested in playing for it. The gig didn’t happen but we realized that we had similar interest, that of writing original music. So we jammed together and put out an Album called Human Race.

strong.span: How did the name Dream Out Loud come about?

p.span: DOL : Much before we got this band together we had painted a picture of us playing gigs, and people singing our songs at gigs, and we wanted to do that not by covering other artists, but with our own original compositions! So lets just say at that point we were Dreaming Out Loud! Hence the name.

strong.span: You perform very regularly in Hard Rock Café and other venues. Describe your experiences performing live?

p.span: DOL : We play live all over India pretty often and the feeling is absolutely unexplainable. There’s nothing in this world that can make you feel , like the way one feels, when the audience connects with you in person. It’s exhilarating!

strong.span: The lead singer of your group, Suraj does a lot of work for Bollywood. How does he manage to switch off and switch on musically between the two styles?

p.span: Suraj Jagan : I don’t need to switch on and off. I love singing. So styles don’t matter at all.

strong.span: Your music is very melodic but also manages to cater to head bangers. What do you think of while writing your songs?

p.span: DOL : One does not think when composing a song. When composing a song one writes about what one is feeling in The Moment. It’s all about feeling & less of thinking. So, I guess the kind of music both of us have grown up listening to, makes us write and compose in a certain way. The kind of music we write, comes very naturally to us.

strong.span: Why did you decide to take the digital route to release your music?

p.span: DOL : The music world has seen a major change. Rather the way music is sold and heard globally has been revolutionized. We know for a fact that digital distribution is the only way to keep in contact with your fans and reach out to them in any corner of the world. Apart from that it gives the listener the power to choose the tracks they want to hear & download!

strong.span: Where do you think the music industry is going? Do you believe that there is a market for non-film music in India?

p.span: DOL : The music Industry is going through a major change. We have so many fans that come to watch us perform and ask us where they can get our songs. I am sure there is a huge market for non-film music waiting to be explored and with effective promotions and platforms like Artistsaloud.com, a lot of artists can reach out to them.

p.span: Shashank : 13th August
Bharath : 25th Feb
Aveer : 29th March
Mahesh : 29th August
Victor : 12th August

strong.span: Your first break in the music scene?

p.span: We don’t know if we can really call it a ‘Break’ , but the first time we performed together as band was in May 2006, as a part for Sunday Jam, in Palace grounds Bangalore, amongst 30 other bands. Call it luck, but a photographer there took a picture of Shashank and put it in a News paper as a part of a promotional article for Sunday Jams. Beginner’s luck?

strong.span: How did you guys come together as a band?

p.span: Aveer and Shashank did their engineering from the same college (REC/NITK Surathkal) and used to play in the college band. Once out of college, and after 2 years of Job, they decided that it was time to pursue their passion as life was becoming really boring. So 3 guys from the college band started Jamming together, eventually 2 remained, got a bassist, a drummer and formed a band. Bharath, joined subsequently, when the band realized that the Key to the sound they wanted, was indeed hidden in Bharath’s Keyboards.

Somewhere is some other part of the world, 2 guys from BITS Pilani, who also used to play together in the college band were leading their lives completely unaware of where their fates would lead them. One of them Mahesh ,decided one fine day that he is going to start playing drums again ( we guess, mainly motivated by his wifes hysterical laughs when he told her he was a star drummer in college). He searched the internet and stumbled upon this band which was looking for a drummer and liked their music. He joined Ek. He brought in the other guy, Victor, the bassist into the band.
Thus Ek was formed.

strong.span: What is the meaning behind naming the group Ek?

p.span: The Band was christened ‘Ek’ by accident if not anything else, mainly due to urgency to get the band registered for their first gig, the Sunday Jam . Shashank thought of the simplest name that came to his mind and got the band registered , thinking, we will change it later. But in retrospect, the name fitted perfectly as it represents the very elements of which the Bands music is made of. Simplicity, yet subtle complexities and different level of interpretations. So that explains why it was never changed. But yes, we did discuss, that if we didn’t perform well at that gig, we will release the version 2, and call it ‘Do’ ( Hindi ) and so on. Thank god we are still ‘Ek’.

strong.span: You had made your music available for free downloads previously. What made you want to release them commercially through ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: We as a band have always felt very possessive about our music, and we are sure a lot of artists feel the same. Till now the only way of making the songs spread to the masses was through the record labels, which in turn resulted in tampering of the songs to make them more Commercially viable. This is something no true artist would like. We as artists have always needed the freedom to create music that is not influenced by factors like: Will this be liked by people? Will this be liked by the record label, will this fit in the script? Is this too complicated? Etc etc…. we need the freedom to express ourselves through our music , when this happens, these songs become more than a commodity. But we always wondered, How do we spread this music to people? As we didn’t have an answer, we put our songs for free download. It took some time, but the right answer did come: ArtistAloud.com.
It was worth the wait.

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach?

p.span: We should be thanking the big demon who came about as a result of the digital and internet revolution. Come-on you know what we are talking about : Piracy. Taking the digital approach is the only way to really befriend this demon and actually use his powers to our advantage.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: We look for a miracle all our lifes . Open your eyes and see, life itself is a miracle. This song is about all those beautiful things that happen all the time which are no less than miracles, only we don’t realize this .We take them for granted. Happy person’s happiness, is visible in his eyes. It’s a miracle.

"If you have a dream, go get it. Period." This is what we, the youth of today, believe in. With all the vigor and enthusiasm, we have set out to achieve the seemingly impossible in every possible facet of life, and know all the way that 'we will win'. Interestingly, the lyrics of this song were written partly while riding a bike and partly while traveling in an Autorickshaw, without pen and paper.

Anything we write about this song will be a give-away. So listen to it and decide for urself. Written on a very bad cold and two pills of Actifed , this is the Bands favorite song. Some understand it, some don’t. But if you do, welcome to the journey.

p.span: We would have been 5 different people, Not Ek.
