Aveer : Stevie Ray Vaughan, Eric Johnson, David Gilmour, Joe Sat, Beatles, A.R. Rehman, Indian Ocean. I'm awed and inspired by many of the Indian classical greats - Pt.Ravishankar, Hariprasad Churasia, Amjad Ali Khan, VishwaMohan Bhat...

Our music is complete when you listen what we play. So keep listening and we will keep playing.

ArtistAloud.com is the answer to the prayers of musicians all over the world. It was high time something of this sort came up. It is the perfect platform for musicians to show-case their songs, their creativity and above all, express themselves, as ‘independent Artists’ and create music without any restrictions or constraints.

With the wide variety of music being created in Indian today, a Platform was needed, which could take this music from the artists to the people, and in the process prevail over piracy. ArtistAloud.com is precisely that.

p.span: 9th July.

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

p.span: Awara Baavaren from the film Sapnay was a major break.

strong.span: You have been in the music scene for quite a while now. You keep disappearing and coming back with a bang. Is that planned or by chance?

p.span: Firm Principal and values, a non compromising nature and also the need to sing with dignity have contributed towards my songs treasury but my Happy-Go-Lucky, Content attitude could also be somewhat a part of the reasons for disappearing now and then, and yet knowing for certain that I will always be back by the grace of god and the will of my dead fans, with whose positive energies all that has been showered upon me has been declared a Hit.

strong.span: You have been involved with various social causes including issues related to women. Can you tell us something about that?

p.span: Since childhood there has been an intense concern in my for the injustice and atrocities heaped on women. I am glad that today my plea for women empowerment (also saving the girl child) is being heard and hopefully adhered to. Saving lovely GOA and concern for children (Drive against drugs and pedophiles) have also been on my agenda. I have been given so much by human beings who have been in their own way from time to time my god and I will always strive to give back extensively my time and energies to such causes.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: is an almost classical SUFI based song, Composed by NAZAKAT ALI and arranged by HYCINTH D’SOUZA. IT is an intense heartfelt call to the heavens to make life more livable for human beings.
is a rocking Sufi Qawwali, which one would want to tap ones feet to. IT refers to ‘YAAR’ as GOD, and describes the love of a Devotee to that one god with many names.

is an ode to women all over the world. It talks about the woman of today who has proved to lead in all fronts whether it is as a mother or as a professional. It is a spunky energetic track sung in English by Hema that promises to become an anthem for women all over the world.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: Am glad I am sincerely also referred to as a social activist which is an integral part of my living and I always wanted to make great , meaningful, issue – solving cinema. Hopefully someday I will inshallah !
GOD of course. My revered Guru SRI RAVI SHANKAR, my family and friends, and an endless list of good people who are actually the real reason why I am answering an interview such as this.
People , most animals, Kindness, Upholding of values respectability to all especially women & Sensitivity & having Fun!!!
Hurting any creature physically or emotionally, Non-concern to human Values, Disrespect to anyone especially Women (I Denounce it) and Insensitivity, and not having Fun!!!
- Too Long List BLAH BLAH
LATE MICHAEL JACKSON
- EARTH SONG BY MICHAEL JACKSON
MY supposedly Happy-Go-Lucky, Energetic & Sincere yet kind of naughty countenance (too many Genuine Endorsement on these) other than the well loved Bhwara Bhavaren Girl’

My gratitude is so deep and from the core of my soul and will strive to never let you down and always respond with all my heart to your love which has been so genuine throughout. Wish you true happiness, success & joy in all your endeavors. God be with you and keep having Fun!!!

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

p.span: Yara Dil Dara.

strong.span: Did you become a music composer first or were you a singer first?

p.span: Always a Music Director first but fortunately could sing well ;).

strong.span: Do you feel it more fulfilling to compose for a film?

p.span: I love composing for films as long as I get an opportunity to make a melodies song.

strong.span: Did you ever get offered to act in a film? If yes, did you take it up? If not, why not?

p.span: I have acted in the film “Jo Jita Wohi Sikander”.

strong.span: Why have you taken the Digital Approach?

p.span: I believe this digital approach allows me to share my songs which I made it for my fans and share those songs which are very close to my heart.

p.span: - The lyrics talk about love expressed through the eyes. The song is very picturesque in its lyrics and takes you into a fantasy land.

p.span: My own Rock Band - Bad Blood in Goa in 1996

strong.span: You are a Christian from Goa living in Delhi with a very strong Hindi influence. It is quite an interesting combination. Does singing in Hindi come natural to you or you have forced yourself to singing in Hindi to be able to reach out to a larger audience?

p.span: My answer to this, 10 years back would be different. But now I am quite comfortable singing in Hindi.

strong.span: You started your career with live shows. Do you feel live is a better way to reach out to your fans or through an audio release?

p.span: Live shows are always the preferred medium but audio release reaches out to audiences far and wide.

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach?

p.span: Digital is the only medium where I can promote my music without me running from pillar to post.

p.span: 31st December.

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

p.span: Live performance at a Hemant Trivedi show, Femina Chrysallis. The whole industry was present, especially those who gave work, I did a good job, Bombay Times supported me via a beautiful article written by Martin D’costa and it was smooth sailing from here on!

strong.span: You are one of the most versatile entertainers in the industry who has built her name through live shows much before releasing an album. How have you achieved that?

p.span: Through my faith in God and in realizing that He is the best manager one can ever hope for! My career has really been a series of miracles and I learnt early on to just do my best and leave the rest to God!!

strong.span: You are now getting into acting. Do you feel this will work better for you as a singer or is it just another feather in the cap?

p.span: Everything I do in the entertainment industry is with a view to promote my music and me as a singer. I have acted before, theatre, serials, but music is my first love and I do believe to be a complete entertainer you must be able to present yourself and your music interestingly and here acting, comparing, modeling, all help tremendously.

strong.span: You have composed, written and sung the songs that you are releasing through this platform. Do you feel it is easier to sing one’s own compositions or when someone else composes for you?

p.span: I believe you know your own compositions better than anyone else and end up giving them more time, more of yourself and more effort, hence they may turn out better overall. The only place it really works for me to have composed the song I have sung is when I am shooting a video because here, knowing the song better than anyone else can really help you emote it the way it needs to be shown.

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach?

p.span: Everything has become digital! No one buys cds the traditional way in a store - except die-hards like me who still like to OWN the hard copy, own a bit of the artiste this way. It’s an exciting medium that is instantaneous, reaches out to millions at once and is the way of the future of music.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: - is one of my favorites! Its sexy, filled with easy-loving, the rain, a great dance groove and it is song that has beautiful lyrics. It’s the kind of song that can help you make-up after a bad fight, make love or just shut out the world and make you happy!

- is the kind of song you can carry on your I-pod and enjoy anywhere! At a dinner, in a lounge, on a long drive I would loop it non-stop. For me music is about spreading the love and forgetting the past and forgiving and moving on. This is the perfect plea for love.

- is, vocally, one of most exciting offerings. It showcases different aspects to me a as singer and I really enjoyed recording this song, setting harmonies, the different arrangements. The fact that we chose NOT to lyrically interpret the chorus was also fun. It different, its soothing and its meant to transport you to a place you love - I hope it does!

p.span: A pilot.

p.span: 28th December 1966

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

p.span: Sony Music’s debut female artist in the country with an album tilted RITIKA released in 2000. Composed by Vanraj Bhatia. Written by Mehboob, Suman Sarin and me. Created video of the song titled HUSN.

strong.span: After your debut pop album, you went into making quite a few children’s albums. How did that come about?

p.span: As an artist I always felt that one area that has been neglected severely in our country is creativity and development of children vis a vis music. If you take a closer look at the albums I have created for children you will find that I have tried to create relevance for Indian children who are usually force fed with Twinkle Twinkle or Humpty Dumpty since ages. Of course Indian children are entitled to a grooming in western culture and school of education, but don’t you think they deserve a lot more than conventional nursery rhymes?

So my journey in edutainment started with my first album of original nursery rhymes titled HAPPY DAY released in 2002 and then I kept creating songs for children in various regional languages apart from Hindi and English.

strong.span: You run an NGO as well. How do you find the time to run that and which would take precedence if you were to choose between your music or running the NGO?

p.span: I am a trained Special Educator having done my Bed in Deaf Education from the Ali Yavar Jung National Institute for the Hearing Handicapped , Mumbai in 1990, and have worked in various capacities with leading institutes in the country. Trinayani was created in 2006 as a sensitization, awareness generating and advocacy group to highlight the strengths of people with disabilities.

Music is not different from breathing for me. And you do not think before you breathe. On the other hand Trinayani is a welfare trust I devote a lot of time to as I use the medium of entertainment to reach out to people and the arts play an important role in this advocacy process.

strong.span: Your music and talent is multi genre and multilingual. Do you believe that to be an asset to you? Also does it help to have a style or be able to sing any style as long its good music?

p.span: I enjoy music from any region, of any language and any style and versatility allows me to sing in different genres. I think it is my strength. However the question is if the industry thinks it to be an asset or not? In my opinion, people would rather you be a Bhajan singer or a Ghazal singer or one who sings soft number, it is very confusing when they are faced with a singer who is at ease with different styles.

strong.span: You have some Bollywood songs to your credit. Does it feel more fulfilling singing for Bollywood or your own music?

p.span: Both are equally fulfilling and challenging. Once you have sung a bollywood song it also becomes your own. Creating your own music is like giving birth , you have to go through labour.

strong.span: Why have you taken the Digital approach?

p.span: Because the world is taking that route. Its simple, easy, quick and the effect is far reaching. Of course if marketed and promoted well people across the universe should be able to access music of artists of Artist Aloud, and that is a big high by itself. I truly enjoyed the feel of the record and still own more than 300 cassettes and many cds, would want to continue to produce music to be released in those formats too.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: in Bengali as a song talks about the cerebral aspect of an eternal traveler for whom the journey itself gives more high than the destination.
in Hindi is a lullaby which takes a person of any age to the bosom of a caring mother.

in raga Brindabani Sarang is an attempt to appeal to those uninitiated into the world of Hindustani Classical Music , as well as connoisseurs of the same, without compromising on the purity of its tradition.
is a song that represents the disillusionment of the youth who looks forward to the realization of false promises by the social pathfinders, for a better world.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: I am so many people even now; I am all that I want to be.
Life, the people in it and experiences and of course Basic goodness of mankind.
Colours
Dishonesty and Cruelty.
ME is a quicker answer, or else there are so so so many. Impossible to name one.
No one person in particular.
Aye Paray So Sehna ji, Sada Magan Main Rehna ji ( a song by Meerabai)
My emotive rendition of songs
Live and enjoy life with abandon, sensitivity, tolerance and love.

Here is Artistaloud.com which says that let just create a category which is ‘Independent’ music that’s original, music that’s mine, music that’s tells you and gives you a beep into my life, my thought, my heart, my soul.

ArtistAloud.com is an initiative believes in the independent voice of the artist community. It’s a platform where different styles, languages, thoughts can be expressed on the premise that good music irrespective of its origin can sell and reach out to a wider audience. All that is needed is conviction and respect for originality.

news.Press_News_Title: Roopkumar and Sunali Rathod on ArtistAloud.com

p.span: Roopkumar Rathod (RR) - 10th June
Sunali Rathod (SR) - 17th February

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

p.span: - It was given to me by the illustrious and the one of my favorite Composer
PT. HRIDAYNATH MANGESHKAR for a song in a film called AASTHA.
- My 1st ever album was launched by H.M.V.-An E P of Gujarati songs Composed by the Illustrious composer SHRI PURSHOTTAM UPADHYAY when I was 17 years.

strong.span: Why have you taken the Digital approach?

p.span: - The future of all industries is going Digitally. Computers are the way of life. Since music is the mirror of the society digital media activity is inevitable.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: - An Interesting and Intoxicating blend of lounge and classical. This Song is sure to catch the fancy of all music lovers.
- High class poetry combined with the new age music. A different experience altogether.
- A True blue fusion between the Indian and western classical. This is a rare bandish in raag des from the vast ocean of Hindustani classical repertoire..

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: - Oh...I would be a Professional Photographer for sure.
- An Actor no doubt
- My Inspiration is Sachin Tendulkar for the sheer determination.He is a true GEM.
- My Mentor, Guide & Guru is Pandit Hridaynath Mangeshkar. Apart from music he has taught me to watch and learn things with different prospective.
- Traveling-Especially to wild life parks.
-Travel to Chilled out Destinations.
- Waking up early for Anything
- Dirty Public places and utility services.
We as a couple and our voice and His creativity.
Keep listening to us.

strong.span: You have been one of the most reticent singers in the Bollywood Industry. Why is that?

p.span: As everyone knows by now, I started my singing career quite late in life - at the age of 25. Till then it was percussion which ruled my life. Besides Bollywood Singing, been very busy with my numerous music concerts hopping round the globe and also composing for non-films albums and films etc keeps me busy. I take things as they come and don’t strive too hard to get it. The journey is most important and not the goal.

strong.span: Do you believe that there are only few who can make it in Bollywood?

p.span: Not any more! There are many different kinds of films with many Genres and Themes being made today. So the change is musicality is inevitable as also the change in vocal aptitude for different songs.

strong.span: What do you feel about all the reality shows in television today? Do you think it is a boon to new talent and a curse to existing talent in the industry?

p.span: I do not particularly enjoy watching reality shows. The new talent which keeps streaming in are at times Good and Bad. Also most of the aspiring singers on these shows lack proper training and devotion required to last long in this field. But yes they do pose a temporary threat to the exiting singers.

strong.span: You have not been seen that often in the music scene? Is that a conscious decision or you were waiting for the right moment?

p.span: My trust with music has been long and arduous one. I have been singing Ghazals, classical, film songs and also western music since I was barely 10 year old. Also I have to my credits 10 odd solo albums starting way back in 1987.

My first Ghazal Album Aaghaaz (the beginning) was launched in 1987 followed by Dil-Kash, Khazana. Unfortunately Bollywood Music generally ruled the music world and I have not rendered many film songs, but my concerts have always kept me busy for past 20 years on the music scene.

strong.span: Except for one solo album with Leslie Louis, you have always sung with husband, Roopkumar Rathod. Why is that?

p.span: Fortunately I and my hubby dear share a passionate relationship as far as music is concerned.

strong.span: Have Roopkumarji and you ever been professional rivals?

p.span: More than rivals he is always been a positively competitive spirit which keeps us on our toes and we strive to achieve more and better musically in each others company. As for instance if I learn a new Bandish (Classical melody) in a certain raga unknown to Roop he is sure to run to his guru and make sure that he learns it too.
The USP of this whole platform is the freedom of expression of all the artist and all the singers
We wish all the Luck!

24th March 1967

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

p.span: A classical concert with Guru Niaz Ahmed Khan Sahib in Bharat Bhuvan in Bhopal

strong.span: Your music has a very interesting youth appeal. Do you feel the youth of today understands music better than in your youthful days?

p.span: Today’s young have more exposure to different Genres of music and therefore have the ability to chose from a wider pie...therefore their understanding and attention is spread across Genres and not narrowly focused on a few.

strong.span: You have a style that grows on listening. How do you perceive your listeners to accept you?

p.span: In today’s time, our listeners are becoming more and more open minded to different styles of music and appreciative of different art and music forms. My style is not different but diversified and adaptive but still conforming to the Genres, so I think they will respect that coming from a single artist.

strong.span: You have performed the world over. Do you prefer performing live or recording in the studio?

p.span: Both have their own exciting moments, and my deep passion for music allows me to enjoy both.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: is a classic rock number, and Naihar Chuto Na Jaye is a semi-classical fusion song...both are targeted towards todays upbeat youth.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: Composer
No single person but every great musician that I have had the opportunity to hear.
Romantic and upbeat music
Heavy noisy music (to my ear, of course)
- Michael Jackson, Lata Mangeshkar
- Shahid Parvez Khan Sahib, Beethoven
- Lag Ja Gale by Lataji, Mere ham nafas mere ham nava by Pakistani Ghazal singer Farida Khanam
My voice.
Wait, there's more to come....Hope you enjoy listening cause I really enjoy singing for you.
It’s a beautiful initiative and a great platform for the individual artist. And I hope for its worldwide success.

13th March 1965.

strong.span: Your first break in the music scene?

p.span: In college, with my band the Les Boys. We were writing our own songs even then, and got our first big break when Doordarshan ( no satellite TV then ) shot a video on our track. It featured me playing Drums and Singing. That video was played for 7-8-years on DD and everyone knew who we were. Even till date people remember me from that video. It was a great track too.

strong.span: You had quite a few successful albums almost a decade ago but you seemed to have disappeared from the scene. Was that intentional?

p.span: Well my first album was English project which received excellent critical acclaim but due to extremely poor marketing it had limited commercial success. Then came the Indi-pop revolution and I've been told by many that my project Tu Hi Tu was in a way one of the spearheads of that movement. The album did really well and helped to establish me as a serious player. Thereafter I released another pop project which also had a pretty decent run but by then the remix bandwagon had totally taken over.

I consider that period as the darkest in the history of Non-Film music in our country as complete non-entities were being made into stars by impotent and incompetent record company executives who had no absolutely no vision or sense of music and thought the remix scam would go on forever.

I was so upset that I made a song and shot a video called "Mujhse banta nahin Remix Kya Karun I'm in a fix" openly criticizing the remix culture as it had denied a generation of artists their due. That album was my 4th solo effort and made it to the top 5 albums of the year.
So I've been around inspite of dealing with all this junk and hanging in there awaiting a revival vehicle like Artist Aloud.

strong.span: You are more known as a drummer. Why did you not pursue a career as a professional drummer and release and instrumental album?

p.span: Yes that’s true, the problem is that it's difficult to find players who are into that level of music which I like to play in terms of drumming. They're only a few and they're all busy doing their own thing. However I'm currently in the composing stage for an instrumental project which will feature me predominantly as a drum artist and hopefully it will be ready by next year.

Yet I have been quite busy on the live performance front as I keep doing Digital percussion gigs all over and have been getting some amazing responses. In fact I've been entered into the Limca book of records for my high speed Double Bass Drumming, it's quite an achievement and I'm rather proud of it.

strong.span: What do you prefer more, singing or playing the drums? What is the most difficult art according to you?

p.span: They're all equally tough or easy. I think it's a matter of natural acumen and then personal practice that will determine your proficiency. Fortunately for me God has gifted me with varied abilities of composing, writing, singing and playing. I’m even recording and mixing my own tracks now, so I’m constantly at it, learning more and more as I go along.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: This is a very special song that I penned in a highly contemplative state, and it’s all true. It’s me speaking aloud to my soul expressing what’s hidden deep inside.
Drums were played live and the solo displays flashes of the high-speed foot Drumming technique that I’ve been entered in the record books for.
Every time I listen back to the track I feel my adrenaline pump and energy flow. Hope you will identify with the grinding emotion and sincerity of thought.
Hot and rocking.

Funk has always been a special genre for me and is one of the strongest roots of my musical foundation. While arranging this track I incorporated the superb artistry of my old buddy and master funk guitarist Jimmy Fernandes.
The vocals are a mix of falsetto and head and I took special care to achieve the smooth finish that has resulted in the glibness of the hook.
Blended with a rave-ish arpeggiation and a sub-low thumping groove, this is a fun and funk track that I’m very proud of.
Chilled listening, enjoy the vibe.

No explanation for his one. It’s just pure surrender and a sublime connection with the Lord. Listen carefully and maybe you’ll hear the tears flow freely in as they did while recording. It has the magic moment that can only come from the cosmos.
Close your eyes and listen……. and then listen again, maybe you’ll hear your own soul.
A perfect reflection of my current state of mind. Having been there and done that, there’s more to it than you can see, if you can only look inside.
Based on contemporary laid-back groove and controlled minimal orchestration it’s the first among my new set of tracks in English coming up.
Adult contemporary, for the discerning listener.
Based on contemporary laid-back groove and controlled minimal orchestration it’s the first among my new set of tracks in English coming up.
Adult contemporary, for the discerning listener.

strong.span: HEAT IN THE MOMENT OF LOVE

p.span: Its my version of clubby stuff, with some intelligence. It’s layered on a base of sensual thinking and words and repagination going wild in tandem with thumpy loops and a clicky but warm bass. The vocal tracks are dipped in a fluid husk and whisper. The lyrics are precise at what they ant to convey.
This one’s for the dancers and lovers alike.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: I've always led a dual life. By day I'm a full time businessman running a Logistics and Customs House agency with strength of over 100 personnel.

My inspiration is my Late father Rammohan Maroo, a man of steel and great spirituality who recognized my passion and allowed and encouraged me to do my music. Without his blessings I would be nothing.
My mentor is my Guru, Dinshah Sanjana, one of the topmost musicians India ever
produced, lives in LA , he is responsible for teaching and nurturing half the industry today.
People with passion who laugh a lot and make others laugh and those who are a little mad.
People who brag and those who lie. I particularly hate those who stab you in the back and think they know everything. I also can't handle people who don't care for their parents and families.
Kumar Gandharva, Lata Mangeshkar and Michael Jackson.
Joe Zawinul, Chick correa, Earth wind and fire, SD and RD Burman and many more.
Impossible to state any one, there are so many.
Unadulterated originality and a sound that one can recognize instantly.
Listen with an open mind and encourage original Indian artists. Enjoy the filmy stuff but remember that we write and sing what we feel, not what someone tells us to.
I would call this a real movement. A movement that will allow Independent Non Film music to be heard and distributed widely from the shackles of big business.
It's the present and the future and a great step ahead. It also displays the solidarity of the artists who have agreed to come together for this movement.
The Artistaloud team deserves great praise for their initiative and effort and I'm sure all the artistes will pledge their whole hearted support to make this a grand success.

On Valentines Day 14th February.

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

p.span: My these two songs releasing on ArtistAloud.com

strong.span: You seem to want to make a mark in the Entertainment Industry by being a model, actor and now also a singer/composer. Did you always plan the route you took or was it by chance?

p.span: Had planned to become a singer a few years back , but while I was preparing I started auditioning and got a few Ads . In this industry you can have goals but sometimes the route you are going to take is very difficult to predict. I like to go with the flow after putting in 100% effort .

strong.span: Most singers become actors or models to gain popularity. Do you believe by getting into singing after modeling and acting you will have an edge over other debutants?

p.span: Yes , in the fact that I also compose , and also the confidence in facing the camera , and yes there will be people who like me as an Actor who might want to see me singing and composing and vice versa .

strong.span: Did you always want to compose yourself or was that the only option to make it in this industry like an actor becomes a producer of his own film?

p.span: In happened by chance, I was focusing on acting and one of my projects got delayed so I dug out some old compositions and worked on them. One thing led to another and these songs were created. In the future am open to working with other composers and using other singers for my compositions. And yes being a composer and singer both have certain advantages and also less pressure for the singer.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: is about how restless a guy is without his love and how his life and environment have become so beautiful because of his love.
is about the spiritual aspect of love , love that makes a person complete , takes the person on a high , and how nothing seems complete without that love .

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: An Actor ( which I already am ).
RD Burman ( music ) , Aamir Khan ( Acting ) .
Honesty , Enthusiasm , Playing Counselor , Spending time with family and friends , watching movies and Madhuri Dixit .
Hypocrisy , Copied Music , Paying exorbitant ticket prices for pathetic films , parties with music so loud you can’t talk , people trying too hard to make an impression , arrogance
- Lata Mangeshkar , Robbie Williams , Sadhna Sargam.
- AR Rahman , Dire Straits , Shankar Ehsaan Loy , Bryan Adams , Vishal Bharadwaj.
Tere Bina Jiya Jaye Na from Ghar , Something Stupid , I have a Dream, Aao Na from Kyun ho gaya na .
Smile on my face ( always )
Keep Smiling, Keep trying, Never give up !!!

I am with Artist Aloud.com because of their belief in the concept of singles which means that each song will get its due and secondly, they gave me complete freedom to work on my song the way I wanted too, which meant that each song came pure from the depth of my life.

p.span: 12th January.

strong.span: What sort of music inspires and appeals to you? Your music is said to be a mix of Sufi and rock. Would you agree?

p.span: I would agree to that but also off late it incorporates other elements like jazz and a lot of African tribal percussion sounds which I used in the Kashmakash song from the movie Sunday. It depends on situation to situation and song to song. With every emotion there’s a different color and different usage of instruments and genres of music.

strong.span: You are known for your amazing guitar playing. Where and when did you start learning?

p.span: I am a self started guitar player and I don’t know if I am an amazing guitar player but I definitely have a unique style of playing as I don’t use the plectrum. I struck the guitar like a sitar I give it a very Spanish and gypsy feel.
Recently I have been taken on by Gibson Guitar Company in India to endorse their brand and have been gifted two beautiful gorgeous guitars by them.

strong.span: You are acting in a film. Is the shift a short term or a long term?

p.span: This is completely a one off thing for this movie Osama as the director is really a good friend of mine and I believe on him. More than that, I also happen to do the music of this film. I am just doing it for fun because it’s not my main line of career. The best part is that I am doing a clean role where I am playing myself.

strong.span: Which role do you prefer the most , a performer, a singer, a musician, an anchor/host or an actress and WHY?

p.span: Although I enjoy whatever I do but I would prefer the role as a singer, performer, and musician initially. Singer because it comes to me so naturally and it runs in my blood. So it comes the first in my mind.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: Bekarari is a very melodic song that talks about the restlessness of the heart all around us. The song has a melonchalolic approach and ends with a longing for more.

- With Na Jaane Kyun, I have taken a simple melody and gave a very contemporary approach by using the combination of acoustic guitar and flute in a very unique combination. The lyrics talk about how I and my heart follow by whatever it says.

strong.span: If not a singer what else you would have been?

p.span: An interior designer for sure!!
Strength is my optimism, focus, and weakness is restlessness and the inability to accept defeat.
Sting. For me he is an institution in music, a complete musician, singer composer and writer.
My Guitar- its on the guitar that I make most of my music.
Let the games begin

strong.span: Any social cause close to your heart?

p.span: I m associated to PETA.
Soul stirring experience. Singing to me is an extension of my as a personality, of what I am. It also means my true nirvana.

strong.span: Your message to budding singers (to make a mark in the industry)?

p.span: Believe in yourself, be original, polish your skill & accept criticism.

Here’s an opportunity to express myself in an infinite way relentlessly. This is what I can do and this is what I want to do. So this is what is going to happen very soon, you’re going to hear my music on this fantastic site very soon.

span.span: 19th October

strong.span: Your first break in the Music Scene?

span.span: Performed a Chhota Khayal in Raga Durga at the age of 4 years, for O.N.G.C.’s annual festival. First ever Professional Concert was at the Sangeet Research Academy (SRA), Calcutta, in front of Maestros of Indian Classical Music, at the age of 19 years.

strong.span: You have been in the industry for a long time but have not gained as much commercial fame as other non-film artists. What do you attribute this to?

span.span: I am told by fans and well wishers that my music has been ahead of its time. But now by HIS Divine Grace and a certain company called ARTISTALOUD.COM, time has caught up with my music and the whole world will embrace it.

strong.span: Your last big project was with Asha Bhosle. Is it easier to compose for others or for oneself?

span.span: Whilst composing for some one else, one has to be OBJECTIVE. Composing for oneself is a conversation with ones soul.

strong.span: You are one of the few classical artists who seems to blend western with Indian very beautifully. How do you manage that? Is it easier having a classical background?

span.span: Since childhood I have had two parallel upbringings in music. On the one hand, in Hindustani Classical Music and Waltz because of my parents (also my Gurus and great Ballroom dancers) and on the other, in Rock n Roll and Broadway because of my sister and cousins. So both the forms of music come naturally to me and there is never any confusion or chaos in my mind, as to the blending of the two.

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach?

span.span: It is the medium which is the ‘present’ and the ‘future’.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

span.span: KHIZAAN KE DIN
- The Lounge New Rendition:

Composed in the mood of Raga Bhairvi, the song is written (lyrics) by legendary poet, the late Jaan Nisaar Akhtar (father of Javed Akhtar). The melody has a strong hook line and the lyrics have a message of romance, flirtatiousness and philosophy. The rendition caresses the mood of Raga Bhairvi {without any adultration}, taking the listener on a roller coaster ride of colourful notes, and is set to a rather ‘foot tapping’ groove... Enjoy!!!!!!
- The Blues New Rendition:

Is an out & out Blues song {groove & lyrics}, set to a jazz - blues harmonic progression. Written {lyrics} by one of the great 18th century ustads of urdu poetry, the late Mir Taqi Mir, the song has inspiring arrangements of Blues Guitar and Trumpet, with choir - like female backing vocals. A beautiful song for a romantic date…………. Enjoy!!!!!!!
- The Rock New Rendition:

A country - pop - rock song, written {lyrics} by Yours truly. A song for outdoors; meadows; etc…. Composed in a ‘sing – along’ melody and set to a ‘clap - along’ groove, this song takes the fancy of all aspirants. Beautifully arranged using guitars, piano, etc, this song is definitely a college students’ candidate.. Enjoy!!!!!!
The Sufi New Rendition:

Sufi lyrics written by Neha Bhasin, Gumrah Qainati and Yours truly, this song grows on the listener. Unique in sound and presentation, the beautiful melody is in the mood of Raga Raageshri and is very ‘sing - along’. With a formidable hook / chorus line and an ustadi gayaki, the song is arranged & produced to catch the listener unawares. Creates a rather romantic - mystical - spiritual mood.. Enjoy!!!!!

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

span.span: Surely a Politician or a Mafia Don.
My three Gurus; Smt. Sudha Mathur , Pandit Sarvesh Chandra Mathur, Shri. K. B. Mann
Spiritual Aesthetics
The Word – ‘No’
Besides my Gurus; Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan - Ustad Vilayat Khan - John Lennon, Paul McCartney, Roger Waters, Sade - Lata Mangeshkar , Asha Bhosle, Mehdi Hassan, Jagjit Singh.
Several; Belonging to the genres of Classical, Ghazal , Rock , Jazz , Jazz Rock – Blues.
BREATHE - Dark Side of the Moon {Pink Floyd}
Melody - Harmony - Groove , Lyrics
Follow your heart. Saadhna {practice} is the only redemption to all things in the Universe.

ArtistAloud.com is an ‘Idea’ whose time has come. It is the ‘Present’ and the ‘Future’ of show business. At a time when more and more people are spending more time on the computer and less time in front of Television, this (ArtistAloud.com) is the place to be in. If performed with sincerity, integrity and dedication, this Endeavour (Artist.Aloud.com) will be the BIGGEST success story of music and show business, in recent times.
Good Luck and God Bless!

p.span: Tauseef & Cheryl
Tauseef: 1st September
Cheryl: 8th June

strong.span: Your first break in the music scene as individuals?

p.span: Tauseef: Started career as a Ghazal Singer since the age of 13.Entered bollywood as a singer and assistant music director to Nadeem Shravan in 1997.
Cheryl: Started Solo Singing career in the year 1990. Was a part of the first girl band in India called Caliche in 1993. Soul Fusion started in 2004.

strong.span: How did the name Soul Fusion come about?

p.span: We just felt that it well suited our combination, as our music is a fusion of two souls, and our musical sensibilities. Soul Fusion is not a genre; it is “US”.

strong.span: What do you believe is the USP in your style and music?

p.span: As far as we think, we are the only Male Female duo in this category and there has never been anyone like us before on the Indian Music scene.

strong.span: After Colonial Cousins, you seem to be the next duo singing in Hindi & English together. Do you fear comparisons?

p.span: Though we belong to the same genre as the Colonials, we have a difference in our sound and style. Also, the most lovely thing audiences will get to hear are our romantic songs, which I guess obviously Colonials could not attempt.

strong.span: Why did you decide to take the digital route to release your music?

p.span: We think that’s the best way to release our music right now, as our music can be available by just a click on the mouse or on the phone keypad. How amazing the whole technology is and we are proud to be a part of it. It’s the quickest way to reach the listener throughout the world.

strong.span: Where do you think the music industry is going? Do you believe that there is a market for non-film music in India?

p.span: With digital media, it’s just another beginning for the music industry and Sky is the limit.
There is a huge market for non-film music if the content is good. Artists need to do their best as there is a huge competition and we guess it’s going to help the listeners to hear better music.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: : It’s a song about the journey of every individual soul to search that element which gets tranquility, joy & love in life.

This song is a Call for Unity, Cry for Justice & A Voice against Oppression. It portrays the feelings of a common man who wants to live just One Moment of Love & Peace, which is hard to find nowadays.
: A romantic track for all those who are in love with Love. A simple, groovy & a youthful song.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: TAUSEEF: I would be a Writer
CHERYL: I would be a Teacher
TAUSEEF: My inspiration is my best friend Cheryl & my Mentor is my Brother Nadeem of Nadem-Shravan fame.
CHERYL: My inspiration is Jesus Christ & my Mentor is Tauseef, my best friend.
TAUSEEF: Reading, Photography, Traveling, Web Surfing.
CHERYL: Reading, Web Surfing
TAUSEEF: Terrorism and Oppression.
CHERYL: Any form of Evil.
TAUSEEF: Mehdi Hassan.
CHERYL: Whitney Houston.
TAUSEEF: Ustaad Rais Khan.
CHERYL: Kenny G.
TAUSEEF: Ranjish Hi Sahi.
CHERYL: One moment in time.
Unique & Perfect blend of Indian - Western Pop Music
We are glad that finally our songs are getting released. We hope that we touch every heart through our music as it comes straight from our Hearts.

ArtistAloud.com is like a big relief to independent artists as they can now reach out to millions with their music. We are proud to be one out of the first 27artists on board and wish every success to ArtistAloud.com

p.span: 5th April 1967

strong.span: Your First break in the Music Scene?

p.span: In 1985, while I was doing musical theatre, I was spotted by Sanjeev Kohli during one of my performances as Sandy in the play “Grease Lightening”. He asked me if I was interested in signing up with HMV (now Sa Re Ga Ma) to do a Hindi Pop album. I took up his offer in 1989 and released my first album Suneeta Senorita. We made a video of the title song which was aired on National Network in a show called POPTIME. The album went platinum.

strong.span: You are one of the few Pop Artists who has managed to survive the demise of POP. What do you feel about that?

p.span: People have been crying about the demise of POP even before it took off which is why I find it very difficult to answer this question
. But thanks anyway. I must say that I am grat
eful to my fans for having been so patient and appreciating my music despite long gaps between albums.
I think the main reason for this is the popularity of my live shows which kept me connected with my audience. Of course the fact that Paree became a classic helped a lot!

strong.span: In your hay days you were appreciated for your performances on stage. Do you feel artists today have it in them, perform the same way?

p.span: Well some have it and some don’t. The only thing I miss is more originality. They all seem to be trying to fit into some mould instead of letting their USP shine through.

strong.span: Your new music displays a maturity in style, subject and vocals. Do you feel you had to do that as a cause or was it a natural progression to your career?

p.span: I think it was a natural progression of my evolvement as a human being and as an artist. I had the chance to write all the songs myself without any interference from record companies or contributions by other composers , so what it resulted in was an expression of who I was at the time. It wasn’t easy , and it was enhanced by the musicians who later on produced it. And it definitely represents a transition in my career in terms of the type of music I will be performing in the future.

strong.span: Why have you taken the digital approach?

p.span: It has been a long journey in the traditional format and having had the satisfaction of creating actual CD’s I felt it was time to reach out to a larger audience , since the way people are listening to music is changing and I wanted to be a part of that.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: is about how powerful Time is and how it influences our life. It is very special as it has a loop by the legendary drummer Lenny White in it, and is based on a Carnatic Raga. It combines drum ‘n’ bass with rap and has a spiritual and soothing groove.

is based on the raag Amrutavarshini , a lilting tune about the beauty of the Indian Woman. The fusion of guitar and sarangi give it a rich, mesmerising feel, which goes perfectly with the effect she has on people.
is a ballad based on a Thumri. It has been inspired by a composition by my mother’s Hindustani Guru Pandit Laxman Prasad Jaipurwale and speaks of love and longing. I have dedicated it to my mother.
Then there is the fast paced Ye Zameen which speaks of the eternal quality of love, promise and life. It has been arranged by a DJ so it is a club tune based on the Carnatic raag Shudha Dhanyasi.

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: An actress and/or a Dancer. ( I do a bit of both anyway! )
My mother, Kamla Sista, herself a Hindustani Light Classical singer who has released several albums with HMV and sung playback and toured with Rafi, Manna Dey, Talat Mehmood, etc.
Passion.
Selfishness.
- Billy Joel
-Billy Joel
- Vienna waits for you- by Billy Joel
My Ethnic-West look of chunky silver jewellery, funky Bindi and jeans was a trendsetter, I am told. And my Bollywood medleys are favorites in my shows.
Without you my music has no meaning. So listen, enjoy and let me know what you think!
ArtistAloud.com deserves all the support and encouragement it can get , coz that is exactly what it is giving artists today. So good luck, and let the music play!!

p.span: Ritesh Ranjan Sahai - 29th July.
Aneeta Uniyal Sahai - 21st February.
Sanjay K. Pathak - 3rd November.
Rahul Srivastava - 3rd July.
Amit Joshi - 16th April.

strong.span: Your first break in the music scene as a band

p.span: First album released in 2004 on Kosmic music.

strong.span: How did you guys come together as a band

p.span: We met, one after the other, for the purpose of making a show in Lucknow during the summers of 1996, everyone to contribute a bit to it. Ritesh with his poems, Rahul and Sanjay with guitars, vocals and composing and Aneeta again with vocals and later with percussions also. We would spend hours together, sometimes even days and nights. We would eat, sing, wander, quarrel and resolve, gossip, ponder and dream together. We came to Pune sometime around November of 2005, Amit joined us here.
Talaash is a beautiful sense of sharing. With the passage of time we became a family, and then a band.

strong.span: You all were based in Lucknow and have a strong Hindi foundation. Do you believe that that is required to sing in Hindi?

p.span: Yes, that way only you get to feel the minute nuances of the language and then be able to express better.

strong.span: Your song is very acoustic. Do you prefer playing unplugged or wired up?

p.span: Surely unplugged, as it suits to our simple music.

strong.span: You have performed the world over. Do you prefer performing live or recording in the studio?

p.span: Performing live is always a preference, you have the spontaneous connectivity. But as we ought to record a creative piece in a studio, we try our best to tap the similar feel of expressions, as in a live performance.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com ?

p.span: Both the songs are nostalgic.

is about the boundless warmth and affection we enjoyed with our neighbours. There are some words or phrases in the song signifying the typical architecture of the houses where we stayed for long. But the very essence of this mohalla (the song) is not limited to a certain part of the land, it is spread all over the country, may be across the world.
is a passionate sport with no age bar. It is so beautiful and vivid. We have tried to cover almost all the emotions and colours, from flying to crying.

strong.span: Your Inspiration or Mentor for the Band

p.span: Inspiration has always been the family and friends. They kept expressing their interest and faith in our work since the very beginning and through all the ups and downs and the odds of life they have always stood by us. And when we think of a mentor we know that the band owes a lot to Sri. Promod Shanker of Delhi, Late A.K.Gargory (dadu), Sri Vinod Chattrerjee, Ustad Gulshan Bharti, Late A.R. Basu (ICCR), Prof. Ruprekha Verma (Ex. VC, Lucknow University), Dr. Sabra Habeeb and Dr. P.K. Ghosh (Lucknow University), all from Lucknow.
Originality and Honesty.
Selfishness and Hypocrisy
Begum Akhtar, Ustad Bade Ghulam Ali Khan, Shobha Gurtu Ghulam Ali, Jagjit Singh, Lata, Kishore, Rafi, Manna Dey, Mukesh, Beatles, Eagles, Simon and Garfunkel.
Ustad Bismillah Khan, Ustad Amjad Ali Khan and Ustad Zakir Hussain, S.D. Burman, Madan Mohan, A.R. Rahman, Frank Zappa, John Williom and Tommy Emmanuel.
Thandi Hawa Ye Chandni Suhani. by Kishore Kumar, Bhor bhai by Indian Ocean, Mai ri.. by Euphoria and Words by Bee Gees.
The Peepal leaf and the sound of acoustic guitar.

By the grace of God, we are on a journey to produce meaningful poetry with soft and soothing melody for our fans everywhere in the world. We expect that this relationship of love shall continue for ever.

ArtistAloud.com is one of the most wonderful things happening in our times. We hope that this would be a big turning point in the lives and career of the innumerable talented artistes across the country, especially for those who have a very little exposure or hardly have that at all.

The platform has offered the artistes a huge opportunity to showcase their work to the world that too without compromising the honesty of the creation. On behalf of the entire artist community we wish that the Endeavour called ArtistAloud.com become a milestone.

p.span: 14th August

strong.span: Your First break in the music scene?

p.span: I got my first break in the Tamil film industry as a playback singer in the year 2003.

strong.span: When did you start singing professionally?

p.span: When I was 7 years old.

strong.span: You are a Bengali who sings in Tamil. How did that come about?

p.span: Ha ha ha it is all about the music and not about the language. I have always had a talent of grasping languages fast and that came pretty handy in Chennai. Since I was in Chennai and Tamil is very big, rather the biggest here so I started singing in Tamil. I have also sung in other languages like Telegu, Malayalam, Kannada and of-course my mother-tongue Bengali apart from Hindi, Urdu, Assamese and English.

strong.span: You have done a lot of work with A.R Rahman. How has that been?

p.span: That probably has been one of the best and most enlightening experiences of my life. It is not only an honor to work with him but as a musician and composer one gets to learn a lot from the way he works. He makes you think like a creator and just not a mere vocalist. I got to re-invent myself in a completely new perspective. One constantly has to upgrade one’s talent. For example, in one of the Tamil songs I had sung for him, I had to modulate my voice in 4 different styles. That’s what he prompts you to do – to re-invent yourself.

strong.span: Why have you taken the Digital approach?

p.span: Why not? You know when compact discs were introduced first in the market after magnetic tapes, people started wondering how it would be with the new technology. But it made life so much easier and less cumbersome. Also the quality of sound became much better. Today with the internet being accessible anywhere and everywhere and cities becoming wi-fi enabled, I think it’s the easiest way to access any kind of music from all over the world. Makes life easier again! It is also another way of reducing music piracy.

strong.span: Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?

p.span: – a melodic mix of Hindustani elements with drum and bass. The song moves around a one line bandish which says mora saiya mo se bole na.

– a haunting melody which has fused the east and the west. I am a melody person and it is very obvious in this number where the song moves through different scales and notes yet merges at one point – the soul of the song which lingers in your ears long after it is over.

– Punjabi folk songs have always inspired me especially the ones which talk about pain and separation. There is something about the tunes and lyrics of these songs which could move even the toughest of human beings. Heer is my attempt to bring out that pain through a simple concoction of notes and words

strong.span: If you were not a singer, what would you have been?

p.span: That is a very difficult question to answer because I have been a singer all my life and though I have also been a corporate woman for seven long years, music has always been a very integral part of my life. I have, as long as I remember, handled two professions simultaneously. It’s only now that I have plunged into music completely.
My mother
A Kind Gesture
Pessimism
Asha Bhosle, Ghulam Ali, Jagjit Singh, Bjork, Geoff Tate (Queensryche) and Tarja Turunen (Nightwish).
– R D Burman, A R Rahman, Peter Gabriel.
– There are too many of them and if I mentioned one I’d do injustice to the others.
My vocal versatility which helps me in treating and rendering each song differently from the other.
Enjoy the music.

It is fantastic that Artist Aloud has opened the door to new and original compositions by a fresh bunch of artists. It is like a breath of fresh air to the otherwise stale musical environment of India. Film music has always had a greater reach among the audience but I hope that with this particular platform a broader and more experimental audience can be reached with these unconventional compositions. All the best to the team of Artist Aloud and thank you for making me a part of it.

news.Press_News_Content:
Suneeta Rao has gone digital with her music to touch base with her fans directly
Photo: Sampath Kumar G.P.
LONG-STANDING SINGER Suneeta Rao has survived a new generation of musicians, to hold her own
“The way people listen to music has changed. CDs were big when I started my career as a singer. Now people want to download music to their PCs and phones,” says singing sensation Suneeta Rao, who has gone digital with artistaloud.com.
Pioneered by Hungama Digital Media Entertainment, artistaloud.com aims at providing an opportunity for independent artistes to connect with their fans. It also attempts to combat piracy by making music directly available to fans, and appears to be a much-awaited solution for musicians who haven't been able to get a commercial release for their original compositions.
Immediate feedback
Ask her why it's important for an established singer such as her to go digital, and Suneeta explains: “When there is a medium that allows one to receive immediate feedback from fans, any artiste would want to use that.”
The alternative pop singer's last release was ‘Waqt' in mid-2008, which received an overwhelming response, and she thinks it is the popularity of the live shows she does between new releases that actually endears people to her. In an age when newer forms and genres of music take shape, Suneeta has managed to remain popular.
But she feels: “The word diva has been used to describe far too many qualities and attributes. I'd rather let my work and my fans stand as proof to the kind of artiste I am.”
Defeats the purpose
On reality shows and music talent hunts, Suneeta says: “Television is a great medium to get exposure. What does stand out about our country is the surge of talent.” However, Suneeta asserts: “There are drawbacks that come with such shows. What happens most often is that people trying to make it big in the music industry live up to a clichéd role model. This defeats the very purpose of trying to find someone new, someone different. There is no originality in many of these shows.”
On future plans, Suneeta says: “My three-month-old baby is my priority, so there isn't too much apart from artistaloud.com that I'm thinking about.” When Suneeta isn't crooning, she dances, performs as a theatre artiste, takes Spanish lessons, travels extensively, and even scuba dives.
NEETI SARKAR

Your Birthday?
Dec 17th
Your First Break in the Music Scene?
I had my first gig as a solo drummer at the age of 5 and many more after that but as a recording artist, my first break came shortly after I was discovered by a music producer during a college band performance. I sang for a compilation album; one of the songs I sang was in Spanish, there after I was considered “into the scene’’.
What do you believe is the USP in your style and music?
It’s pretty much the melody and rhythm. A good melody almost always connects with the listener over a longer period of time. Being a dancer, I have a penchant for digging rhythm and experimenting with sounds. In my music I like to put a ‘Bling Moment’; this could be anything from beat-boxing (which I do), a catchy interlude or the ‘stop n go’ of rhythm - a structure that suddenly turns the song around and back again. Also, I believe my singing style has its own individuality.
How do you believe music should be consumed?
Like what we are doing here, selling music online is the quickest way to reach out to people across the globe. This combined with clever marketing and promotion! However, true fans are most likely to buy a CD off the shelf. As a performer, touring and performing live is one of the best ways I can connect to people, let them relate to the artist they are listening to, let them consume your personality along with the music, let them be mesmerized. I’d want my audience, when they go back after the show to say, “I gotta watch that again!” Give them an experience.
Who do you see connecting to your music?
When I’m making my music, I honestly don’t decide a particular section of listeners to aim it at. I just do it! I’m a storyteller, I tell a story and then that story finds its way through a melody, a rhythm, instruments and my voice ; who so ever can relate to those stories, will be able to relate to my music. Geography no bar!
Why did you decide to take the digital route to release your music?
Let’s face it- the traditional music business is crumbling and it's now the Do-It-Yourself Era. At no time in history have independent artists had so many opportunities to create high-quality music and sell it to the masses. And what's the main thing that's driving this incredible change? The Internet -- where millions upon millions of people go every day to search for new music. Why only the World Wide Web? Throw in the mobile and DTH technology too! The buzz word is- Connect! People can instantly get the music (read: Legally) in the comfort of their bean bag or palm. I’m looking at the future and beyond; the endless possibilities gives me such a rush!
Where do you think the music industry is going? Do you believe that there is a market for non-film music in India?
The entry of new age composers who are from nontraditional ‘filmy’ background has brought about the change in the sound and blurring the divide between non filmy and filmy music. What an independent artist needs is a sellable product and a genius marketing. I won’t mince my words; it’s all about being able to sell!
Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?
T.D.M.(Tere Dil Mein) is my first single on ArtistAloud.com. I penned and composed this song a few years back and recorded a demo. The song tells a real life story of that time. As usual, I tend to spend a lot of time on each record I produce; putting each sound under the microscope and giving it a character. The same happened with TDM and then a rude shock of deadlines sank in! It was crazy towards the end; living literally in the studio. Finally, after a long wait its out for the world and my sincere thanks to ArtistAloud.com for initiating it.
If not a singer what else you would have been?
I already have a second stable career as an Entrepreneur, Animation Film Maker and a Visual Artist. Seriously, I hate the sound of “If not a musician, then?”
Your Favorites
Singers- Many! To name a few; Kishore Kumar, Frank Sinatra, Sting, Bono,Usher, Michael Jackson, James Brown, Eddie Vedder, Bruce Springsteen, Rhydian, Annie Lennox..Ok too many!!!
Songs- Dude, you could have asked me about quantum physics rather.
Your strengths and your weakness?
Music vs. Music
Your Inspiration or Mentor?
I do take inspiration from some of the greatest in the music, film and entertainment business for their respective expertise ranging from stage presence, presentation, entertainment value to vocal dexterity and dancing skills.
Along with these, I’m always inspired by my parents (who are also musicians) for the amount of tireless energy, hard work and dedication they have put in over the years.
Your most prized possession?
My voice for you to listen and my body for it to move.
Your Favorite Quote?
What we think, or what we know, or what we believe is, in the end, of little consequence. The only consequence is what we do.
Your Trademark?
Hahaha..ummm well, my hats, belts, my moves and showmanship I guess.
Any social cause close to your heart?
Yes, I’m associated with a few NGOs and other organizations for causes like Education, health and social welfare. I don’t really like to talk about them though.
Singing to you is?
Like making love. It makes my heart, mind, body and soul work in culmination; where I relish giving the joy as much as deriving from.
Your message to budding singers (to make a mark in the industry)?
Be prepared as an artist. Believe in what you can deliver and at the same time, be your own honest critic. Don’t try too hard to be different from the rest, just be aware of it at a subconscious level.
Also please give a few lines about ArtistAloud.com.
AristAloud.com is a dream come true for all independent singers and musicians. We really needed something like this and they came just in time! My heartfelt best wishes to the entire team.

The Internet -- where millions upon millions of people go every day to search for new music. Why only the World Wide Web? Throw in the mobile and DTH technology too! The buzz word is- Connect! People can instantly get the music (read: Legally) in the comfort of their bean bag or palm. I’m looking at the future and beyond; the endless possibilities gives me such a rush!

The same happened with TDM and then a rude shock of deadlines sank in! It was crazy towards the end; living literally in the studio. Finally, after a long wait its out for the world and my sincere thanks to ArtistAloud.com for initiating it.

news.Press_News_Content:
Your Birthday?
30th October 1971.
Your First Break in the Music Scene?
Singing at a friend’s party and got noticed.
What do you believe is the USP in your style and music?
The tone, the ideas, the energy, expressions, love of the work I do.
How do you believe music should be consumed?
As it comes. Just choose what s good for you as you would choose good oxygen over toxic.
Who do you see connecting to your music?
A little stream becomes a river as tributaries add up and flows to the ocean. Nothing happens alone. Music is by everyone, for everyone and of everyone. Have I answered your question?!!!!
Why did you decide to take the digital route to release your music?
I like going by the ways of the world. High “tech” is what I love to “take”. Ha ha ha.
Where do you think the music industry is going? Do you believe that there is a market for non-film music in India?
Music always goes in the right direction. Perceptions differ. Hurdles get diversified but music spells the same way always. Non film needs a different approach for sound and presentation to make it big in India through its film extravaganza. Effort in the sense of style, genre and magnitude of promotion must play together to make it heard loud.
Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?
Tumi acho bole means “because of you”. Like Bengali beauty Bengali/Bangla musical emotion is jhakkas too. Just hear it once !
If not a singer what else you would have been?
A tape recorder !!! ultimately singing. Ha ha ha.
Your Favorites
Singers – Pandit Ajoy Chakraborty, Kishore Kumar, Shahnaz Rahmat Ullah, Abdul Aleem, Neena Hamid, Gloria Estefan, Natalie Cole, Frank Sinatra, Nazia Hasan, Diana Ross, Sade.
Your strengths and your weakness?
My strength is my voice and tonal quality and the ability to make it better everyday. Weakness is not be able to transcend my weakness like late nights and chocolates.
You Idolize, Why?
Pandit Ajoy Chakraborty and AR. For - Endurance, hard work, hard work, hard work and Modesty.
Your Inspiration or Mentor?
My son. Why? He falls and gets up smiling.
Your most prized possession?
My education - from home, from out there, from schools.
Your Favorite Quote?
Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn't do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore. Dream. Discover.
Any social cause close to your heart?
Dying away with our two eyes when a hundred people needs each of it. So cornea transplant is issue number 1. muslim girls get only a third of the parents’ property if they don’t have a brother. That’s silly in this context when women know how to fight men. That s issue 2. I work with WFP with their project of feed the child to school.
Singing to you is?
Breathing.
Your message to budding singers (to make a mark in the industry)?
Dream on, don’t let anything stop you.
Also please give a few lines about ArtistAloud.com.
I am excited to have you in my life. I hope you take me to the hearts of people who would not have otherwise heard me. I hope you make a huge mark in my life. And I hope we live together as long as you live.

Why did you decide to take the digital route to release your music?
I like going by the ways of the world. High “tech” is what I love to “take”. Ha ha ha.

Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?
Tumi acho bole means “because of you”. Like Bengali beauty Bengali/Bangla musical emotion is jhakkas too. Just hear it once !

Dream on, don’t let anything stop you.

news.Press_News_Title: Lal Chandra and Himanshu Chawla on ArtistAloud.
news.Press_News_Content:
Your Birthday?
Himanshu - 29th Nov 1988.
Lal Chandra - 2nd Oct.
Your First Break in the Music Scene?
Himanshu - Got Album with Mr. Lal Chandra.
Lal Chandra - All India Radio, Purnia, 1995.
What do you believe is the USP in your style and music?
Himanshu - Creativity & Next Generation connect.
Lal Chandra - A strong Indian Classical base and experience of various type of popular music form like folk and Sufi genre.
How do you believe music should be consumed?
Himanshu - Music Cds, Internet.
Lal Chandra - Apart from being just a form of entertainment and relaxing affair it holds and shows the ways of life in ups and down and uplifts our soul.
Who do you see connecting to your music?
Himanshu - My Soul.
Lal Chandra - The mass in general and those too who take music a bit more importantly in life.
Why did you decide to take the digital route to release your music?
Himanshu - Because I think these days 90% of people use internet or some another digital routes to listen to the music.
Lal Chandra - I think this is the best way to reach to the mass – whether the urban or the rural, it’s accessible everywhere in the present time.
Where do you think the music industry is going? Do you believe that there is a market for non-film music in India?
Himanshu - Music is an important part of any occasion starting from child birth to anyone’s demise, it is an integral part of most of the people around us and hence is growing phenomenally & has an immense potential to develop further.
India being a country of such a vast population with diverse backgrounds and culture gives an enormous opportunity for non film music.
Lal Chandra - I believe a consciousness is growing toward a wider aspect of music, and non-film music making a strong place in the industry.
Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?
Himanshu - Chalta ja is a motivational song which gives a message to keep moving always, no matter whatsoever happens the most important thing is to walk towards your destination.
Music is light & soothing & I expect that it will be appreciated by all.
Lal Chandra - The song ‘Chalta jaa’ is about positive motivation in life whatever difficult situations we face, we have to go ahead!
If not a singer what else you would have been?
Himanshu - A Creative Music Director.
Lal Chandra - Could not think about any other profession since my conscious being… possibly a good listener of music!
Your Favorites
Himanshu-
Singers - Sonu Nigam, Rahat Fateh Ali Khan, Sukhvinder Singh
Musicians - AR Rahman
Songs - O re Piya, soona soona- sonu nigam, Jai ho and many more
Lal Chandra-
Singers - Pt. Kumar Gandharva, Shankar Mahadevan.
Musicians - A R Rahman
Songs - Jo tujhe jagaye.
Your strengths and your weakness?
Himanshu - My parents are my strength and my emotional behaviour is my weakness.
Lal Chandra - Hard working i.e. ‘riaazee’ ; introvert.
You Idolize, Why?
Himanshu - AR Rahman: Self made creative music director.
Lal Chandra - That shows the way ahead.
Your Inspiration or Mentor?
Himanshu - Salim Suleiman,and AR rehman.
Lal Chandra - My guru, Pt. Mithilesh Kr. Jha.
Your most prized possession?
Himanshu - My interest for music.
Lal Chandra - My learning of music.
Your Favorite Quote?
Himanshu - Be Positive.
Lal Chandra - ‘Chalta jaa’ Move ahead.
Your Trademark?
Himanshu - My favourite line-“WHERE WORDS FAIL MUSIC SPEAKS”.
Lal Chandra - My voice.
Any social cause close to your heart?
Himanshu - Not yet.
Lal Chandra - Helping others.
Singing to you is?
Himanshu - Soul of the music.
Lal Chandra - Life.
Your message to budding singers (to make a mark in the industry)?
Himanshu - Just keep on moving, don’t look behind, do your best and leave the rest.
Lal Chandra - Hard work and dedication.
Also please give a few lines about ArtistAloud.com.
Himanshu - I m very thankful to this website as this is a huge platform for the budding artists/musicians who have hidden talent but have not got an opportunity to demonstrate it.
Lal Chandra - May this be the best platform to reach the voices of new talents to a wider audience.

Press_News_Featured.p:
Why did you decide to take the digital route to release your music?
Himanshu - Because I think these days 90% of people use internet or some another digital routes to listen to the music.
Lal Chandra - I think this is the best way to reach to the mass – whether the urban or the rural, it’s accessible everywhere in the present time.

Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?
Himanshu - Chalta ja is a motivational song which gives a message to keep moving always, no matter whatsoever happens the most important thing is to walk towards your destination.
Music is light & soothing & I expect that it will be appreciated by all.
Lal Chandra - The song ‘Chalta jaa’ is about positive motivation in life whatever difficult situations we face, we have to go ahead!

Your message to budding singers (to make a mark in the industry)?
Himanshu - Just keep on moving, don’t look behind, do your best and leave the rest.
Lal Chandra - Hard work and dedication.

Give a few lines about ArtistAloud.com.
Himanshu - I m very thankful to this website as this is a huge platform for the budding artists/musicians who have hidden talent but have not got an opportunity to demonstrate it.
Lal Chandra - May this be the best platform to reach the voices of new talents to a wider audience.

news.Press_News_Content:
Your Birthday?
3rd July, 1978.
Your First Break in the Music Scene?
Dec. 2000 (1st professional show, not amateur as was doing during college days before that).
What do you believe is the USP in your style and music?
Versatility (soft pop to hard rock, Hindi & English both), power and range of voice. Also, I write, compose n sing my own songs.
How do you believe music should be consumed?
Music should be neither heard, nor felt - IT SHOULD BE JUST BREATHED IN AND SUCKED INTO UR BLOOD!!!!
Who do you see connecting to your music?
Anyone who’s ALIVE!
Why did you decide to take the digital route to release your music?
This way it reaches the masses with least possible hindrances, no red-tapism here!
Where do you think the music industry is going? Do you believe that there is a market for non-film music in India?
I believe we deserve to make n hear better music than we’re currently listening to. There certainly is an immense market for all kind of music, if only we explore it, makes it reach the people, the masses!!
Can you say a few words about each of the songs you have on board ArtistAloud.com?
SAVERA: My only song here yet, it’s my salute to the undying human spirit. Conceptualized during a visit to one of the rehab centers after meeting the inhabitants there, it gradually grew into an ode to all who’ve had the guts to fight the odds of life ever!! It motivates, it awakens, it arouses, it makes alive the dormant strength in you n me!!!
If not a singer what else you would have been?
Ummm has to be a wannabe singer.
Your Favorites
Singers: Celine Dion, Mariah Carey, Amy Winehouse, Amy Lee, Steven Tyler, Axl Rose, Lata Mangeshkar, Asha Bhonsle, Kailash Kher….many more
Musicians: R.D. Burman, S D Burman, Guns n Roses, Aerosmith, Eric Clapton and many others
Songs: Other than my own, it’s a Long list again….these days,
it’s:Thank You for Loving Me,This I Love, Falling Slowly, Back To Black,Tum Jo Mil Gaye Ho (old),Mujhe Mat Roko (mujhe yaar ke ghar jaane do), I really have many many more favourites!!!
Your strengths and your weakness?
I’m a workaholic, a perfectionist and a bit too idealistic (sometimes foolishly idealistic!). I guess my same strengths sometimes serve as my weaknesses too! Also, I’m extremely moody!
You Idolize, Why?
Honestly, I don’t idolize PEOPLE…..i idolize their qualities….no one is perfect!
Your Inspiration or Mentor?
It started from my parents….coz they fed me music ever since I was born; my teacher….coz he made me taste some real good music n made me fall in love with it all over again; and my husband…..he made me realize how DEEP I had it in me n also that I need to make it reach the people!!
Your most prized possession?
My heart, my soul….the day I stop feeling, I’d cease to be!
Your Favorite Quote?
Think before you utter words that give someone pain; wounded hearts are slow at healing, IF they ever heal again!
Your Trademark?
My voice.
Any social cause close to your heart?
I’d pray to be given a chance to work for the support n understanding of the younger generation. With parents being too career oriented, children take a back seat, mostly after being borne. And then, unfortunately, they’re traumatized more by being blamed for being selfish, reckless, without values etc. We forget….they ARE what we’ve MADE out of them. I’d like to work in support of the kids, so they don’t ruin a perfectly beautiful life they’ve been given!
Singing to you is?
Religion, Love, Passion, Breath.
Your message to budding singers (to make a mark in the industry)?
Go where your heart takes you. The path might get, WILL get difficult somewhere, but who said love was easy anyway?
Also please give a few lines about ArtistAloud.com.
It’s really a pleasure to be associated with artist ArtistAloud.com. For the past many years, people have been making music, and it never reached where it was supposed to reach1 ArtistAloud has initiated a great movement, a revolution by making the right kind of music reach the deserving ears! God bless their efforts!!
